SPEAKER ID 23 LANGUAGE PT NAME Cunha Mr President Commissioner I believe that this is an appropriate initiative and that it makes very good sense. As various Members have already commented we often encounter situations where there is an enormous contradiction between our intentions in terms of development and cooperation policy and the damage we inflict with our other sectoral policies whose objectives run counter to development in those countries. And we are not just talking about the concrete impact of our common policies tourism the environment agriculture fisheries and industry. We are talking in general terms and this is more serious about contradictions between our economic and trade policies and our defence policies. So there is a whole raft of contradictions. P In my opinion these contradictions are not all that serious in terms of Community policies. They are if anything more serious as regards certain objectives and industries in some Member States. We have to be aware of this. We often adopt resolutions on peace processes in other parts of the world as was recently the case with Indonesia GPE when we protested at the top of our voices only to discover subsequently that some European NORP countries had been supplying them with arms and military equipment. For me these are the most serious contradictions in all this more serious than the contradictions inherent in any incompatibility between sectoral policies. We obviously know that even within any one CARDINAL country there are always contradictions between various policies. That is a fact of life. And we must also be aware that there will be contradictions between the various Community ORG policies in this case development policy. We have to be aware that these contradictions exist and that we need to minimise them. The underlying reason for presenting this resolution is that the objective of minimising these contradictions is a fair and wise one. I believe that it is both proper and fitting to set up a centre for monitoring this coherence between Community policies and development and cooperation policy and that this monitoring centre s sphere of activity should not be limited just to Community policies but should also cover Member States actions and policies including the actions of economic groups which I think are also important. This monitoring centre should draw up an annual DATE report on developments in these policies and on their impact and interaction. P I have left to the end a question that I regard as fundamental and which I think needs to be noted and approved by this House ORG . Our objective of minimising contradictions between development and cooperation policy and other policies has to be a valid objective not merely within the European Union ORG but also at world level given the increasing globalisation of the economy. If we want fair world trade we will have to gain acceptance for this principle during the next WTO ORG round of multilateral negotiations because it would be contradictory if the European Union ORG imposed a rigid but fair discipline on itself only for the United States GPE and the other major powers to do the opposite and to take advantage of our restraint. That is why I consider it to be essential and fair for these principles to be established at the next WTO ORG round. SPEAKER ID 24 CARDINAL NAME Howitt PERSON Mr President the Director General of the DG for Development has said that to produce a report on coherence of EU ORG policies with development policies before this spring s paper on development policy itself is like putting the cart before the horse. Never mind that the Commission ORG s requirement to produce an annual DATE report set out clearly in the Council ORG resolution has produced only one non paper the real problem here is that at the time of rising world poverty this particular horse is climbing uphill and the cart of other EU ORG policies is so heavy that development policy is actually being pulled slowly backwards. P Time after time development policy is forgotten or is an afterthought when the major policies of this European Union ORG are considered. Take the new chocolate directive which shows that EU ORG countries spend more on chocolate every year than on development aid. There has been no proper development assessment of this directive which the producer countries 90 CARDINAL of which are our ACP ORG partners estimate could cut incomes to cacao GPE farmers by at least 15 CARDINAL . P Take the fishing agreements where we recognise the unsustainability of current fishing practices within the EU ORG waters. We are at the same time negotiating joint ventures allowing increased access for Europe LOC s large scale fishing vessels in developing country waters at the expense of 190 million CARDINAL small scale fish workers in those countries world wide. P Take the trade agreements. As Mr Nielson PERSON said this morning TIME with regard to Lom preferential access is only for essentially all the products of the least developed countries . In other words when EU ORG commercial interests are concerned poverty considerations go out of the window. P In the stance that we took at Seattle GPE why such a silence on the EU ORG s failure to implement the trade concessions for developing countries already agreed in the GATT ORG including for the crucial textile sector? P On the common agricultural policy the biggest culprit no development impact assessment of the Agenda 2000 CAP ORG reforms. Everyone now knows of the scandal of the export refund scheme which dumped 54 000 QUANTITY tonnes of excess subsidised beef on West African NORP markets slashing prices for local cattle farmers by half CARDINAL . Today DATE beef stocks stand at 300 000 tonnes QUANTITY . Who will be next quite literally for the chop? P I welcome Mr Amadeus statement this morning TIME which acknowledged the difficulties of non budgetisation of the EDF ORG which called for a more active role for the Development Council ORG and which called for development priorities to be central to the EU ORG s emerging common foreign and security policy. P I welcome too the Council ORG declaration of 1992 DATE its resolution of 1997 DATE and successive changes in the Treaty of European Union EVENT . Action simply has not been taken. That is why we want annual DATE reports we want an annual inter service group and we want a complaints procedure to make sure action is actually taken. I ask Mr Nielson in his summing up to directly address those points in the resolution. SPEAKER ID 25 LANGUAGE NL NAME Mulder Mr PERSON President I would like to restrict my contribution to the link between development cooperation and agriculture. P Over the past couple of years DATE a considerable share of the funds has been channelled towards the development of agriculture and cattle breeding in the developing countries and more especially the Lom countries. The results are certainly not what we expected. What could be the cause of this? P I think that the cause should first ORDINAL and foremost be sought in the lack of clear agricultural policy in the various developing countries barring a few exceptions. I think that the Commission could do a great deal there to help this develop. No farmer anywhere in the world will produce something if prices are too low. The governments in the developing countries are always faced with a difficult dilemma whom should they support the farmers or the people in the large cities who want cheap food? P This fine balance must be struck in conjunction with the Commission and not by the Commission on its own. In most countries where the Commission is active development aid is also granted by the Member States themselves. It should not be the case that the policy of the Member States contravenes that of the Commission. It is up to the Commission ORG s delegations in the developing countries to assume a leading role in the development of this political dialogue and to ensure that all countries follow this line of approach. P Special attention is also required for the costs of the means of production. Far too often artificial fertiliser veterinary medication and a host of other items are provided to farmers free of charge. Once the project comes to an end after five years DATE the policy of free gifts also ends. I think therefore that the cost element should be built in right from the outset in the policy of all projects and as far as I know this is not the case by any stretch of the imagination. P Finally I wonder whether the funds could not be put to better use. Every year I notice in the budget of the Commission and in the European Development Fund ORG that they are far behind in spending the funds. SPEAKER ID 26 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL NAME Maes PERSON Mr President Mr President in Office of the Council ORG Commissioner we are in actual fact holding a debate amongst the converted which is a pity. We should really talk about coherence in the development policy in the presence of Mr Prodi for example who has missed a great chance right from the outset for he has allowed the development cooperation policy to fragment over three CARDINAL Commissioners and this is better than four CARDINAL I have to admit but this does not really make for a coherent policy. P We also note that as before there are still various DGs which stifle this policy with often very conflicting procedures and arguments. The President in Office of the Council ORG came up with a good suggestion namely to budget the European Development Fund ORG . Parliament ORG would of course welcome this with open arms. If this were possible it would be a huge historic victory. P Since Amsterdam three CARDINAL terms have taken centre stage complementarity coordination and cohesion. I believe that very little has been achieved in these three fields. If a request is made for a report on the progress made on cohesion if a request is made at all then drafting such a report cannot be very difficult unless one simply admits that there is no cohesion at all. I would prefer it if a report were to be written on the present lack of cohesion and if a systematic strategy were to be developed to reach a certain level of cohesion for it is a long way off yet. P One CARDINAL thing shocked me in the speech of the President in Office of the Council ORG . He stated Contradictions in policy can lead to balance. It is indeed the case that what one hand gives can be taken away by the other hand and vice versa. But this leads to status quo and self deceit and globalisation as a whole has so far only led to changes indeed but changes which have only made poverty worse. This is supposed to be our priority would you believe. P I know that we do a great deal of good but let us start with this very essential aspect. SPEAKER ID 27 LANGUAGE SV NAME Eriksson Mr President we have already noted that there is no report from the Commission but I intend to discuss three CARDINAL matters in the light of the objectives which the Council ORG presented in its 1997 DATE opinion. P The first ORDINAL is concerned with conflict resolution. For many years DATE I have tried through the Council and the Commission ORG to find out why none of the institutions is actively participating in and working for conflict resolution in the Western Sahara which is occupied by Morocco GPE . The UN ORG has a peace plan. We ought to seize this opportunity and bring the last colonial episode in Africa LOC to an end. P I also want to take up the subject of migration. I am anxious about the new stipulations in the partnership agreement with the ACP ORG countries which might make it easier to expel immigrants asylum seekers and refugees on flimsier grounds. P I really also want to see the EU ORG pioneer patents on living organisms. We now know that at least one CARDINAL person in the world dies of hunger every four seconds TIME . Three quarters CARDINAL of those who die are children under five years of age DATE . This is not because of a lack of food but because of what we have talked a lot about today DATE namely increasing poverty. Food safety and the guarantee of biological diversity must take precedence over commercial interests. I believe that patents on living organisms are designed only to control the global food supply specifically for commercial purposes and for no other reason. P I also want to see something about women in the report I hope the Commission will produce. Women appear to be completely absent from all areas especially development policy when of course we are not in reality absent at all. SPEAKER ID 28 LANGUAGE SV ORG NAME Wijkman Mr PERSON President the debate we are holding today DATE strongly underlines the need to discuss development policy in much broader terms than are involved in simply measuring the flow of aid. The level of aid is naturally important and the level of aid contributed by the rich countries as a whole ought to be increased. This ought to be done with in particular a view to combating poverty and through investing in the development of capacity. However the level of aid is only one of many instruments which significantly influence the development of poor countries. P A number of colleagues have today DATE pointed to areas in addition to aid which are important and where contrasts and conflicts between different policy areas are very serious indeed. The latter include trade agricultural and fisheries policies. Other important areas are of course the flow of private investments cooperation on research and technology and the way in which the welfare state deals with and finances solutions to a variety of global problems which affect us all. These problems include questions of climate health issues biodiversity etc and the problems are clearly exacerbated by globalisation that is to say the new economy which is developing. In this economy the connection between different policy areas is that much more marked. In my opinion what we are discussing here today DATE is partly the EU ORG s contribution to the debate about the opportunities and risks of globalisation and about the rules there must be in order to give poor countries a decent chance. P The report or survey which Mrs Maij Weggen ORG has demanded showing how the various policy areas fit together and what the aforementioned conflicts appear to be is naturally quite crucial. I cannot help but wonder why the Commission ORG has not done more. The Commission is new and has to be given time but the absence of such a survey suggests that there are powerful tensions within the Commission. I can only hope that Mr Nielsen will be successful in the forthcoming discussions within the Commission. P In addition to a report of this kind I should like to see a more positive analysis which could be ongoing in character. An analysis of this kind should look not only at the flow of aid but also give comprehensive consideration to all the different types of aid and transfers of resources which influence poor countries. These include technology trade cooperation in the field of research etc. It should be an extremely constructive contribution to the debate we are conducting. P Finally Parliament recommends in paragraph 6 CARDINAL of the draft resolution that a working party should be established in order to bring about coherence. I believe it is only a coincidence but the Commissioner for the Environment is also of course to participate in this group. P Let us hope that the debate in which we are now engaged will prove to have been a watershed. Policy so far has been characterised far too much by a process of giving with the one hand and taking away with the other. There are a lot of people who will be watching further developments with great interest. SPEAKER ID 29 CARDINAL NAME Purvis Mr PERSON President the Seattle GPE demonstrators argued that free trade is bad for the less and least developed countries it is purely a rich country selfish interest. P Yet we might consider the rate of economic progress and the rate of eliminating poverty in countries such as India GPE and Tanzania GPE over the 40 or 50 years since they became independent. There the theory went that protectionism and state intervention would preserve jobs allow industry to adjust gradually and without pain. It did not work poverty became worse than ever. P The medicine may not taste too good in the short term but opening one CARDINAL s economy to competition at home and abroad forces optimal application of resources and leads to a higher standard and quality of life in the not so longer term. P Is that not the lesson of the European Union ORG itself and of the single market in particular? As Mr Nielson PERSON said this is a fine example to those countries and regions aspiring to greater prosperity. P Yet preaching the benefits of free trade to the developing countries is not enough. We also have to practise what we preach in our own accessibility for imports from these countries. Parliament s resolution on the WTO ORG negotiations advocated a free import policy by the EU ORG . Eliminating all remaining barriers to imports tariff barriers and quotas and just as important non tariff barriers such as Mrs Maij Weggen mentioned in her speech eliminating these barriers would do more than any amount of development aid to secure for developing countries the economic progress which both we and they desire. P It is quite clear that a lack of coherence of development policy with trade policy diminishes our development efforts and must also diminish the political regard of the developing countries for Europe LOC and our fine words. SPEAKER ID 30 CARDINAL NAME Van Orden Mr President in the last couple of days DATE we have heard fine words about the need for greater coherence coordination and effectiveness in the external aid programmes of the Community and of the Member States. There is one CARDINAL relatively small area of activity with enormous public visibility which would be a litmus test of the Union s ability to match words with action. I am referring to the continuing tragedy of anti personnel landmines which present an obstacle to so many development programmes to post conflict reconstruction and which ruin the lives of many of the most vulnerable in some of the poorest parts of the world particularly in developing countries. P Over recent years DATE the Community ORG has spent some EUR 200 million in mine clearance assistance to victims and related activities. The Member States have spent similar amounts. But there is still enormous inefficiency and a lack of will to implement a strategy agreed with other members of the international community to overcome the anti personnel landmine problem within a finite time span. P Mr Nielson PERSON identified the problems of lack of concerted action and the need for better complementarity with Member States. This has been talked about for years DATE . The Commission needs to carry out internal organisational changes strengthen the coherence and effectiveness of its actions ideally with a properly resourced central mine action policy cell. It would also need more rapid contractual and implementation procedures and an enhanced multiannual budget line and much improved management of its programmes. P A proper stock taking of the effectiveness of mine action programmes needs to take place in each of the countries seriously afflicted by landmines. It seems to me that the landmine issue encapsulates so many of the organisational procedural financial management and operational difficulties which have afflicted the Commission ORG and the Union. Are these afflictions of the past or will we find that in this relatively compact and limited area the European Union ORG is still unable to meet its aspirations? SPEAKER ID 31 LANGUAGE DE NAME Laschet Mr President Commissioner Nielson PERSON the conclusion of the new ACP EU Convention ORG is an important step towards greater coherence. And it is to be welcomed that criteria such as human rights democracy rule of law and good governance are more firmly anchored in this new treaty than they were previously and that earlier colonial relations no longer shape most of our relations to quite the same extent rather we now set greater store by these political criteria in this respect. For these are prerequisite to any development. If these criteria are not adhered to then development does not stand a chance P The same goes for Cuba GPE Mr Modrow GPE . I welcome the fact that Cuba GPE is getting closer to joining this process. But for this to happen there are also going to have to be a few changes in Cuba GPE . After all we are all familiar with the reports from Amnesty International ORG . It may well be that you having belonged to one of the last Communist NORP dictatorships view the situation somewhat differently to the majority of people in this Chamber and that you have problems where good governance is concerned. Nonetheless these are important criteria for the European Union ORG . P There is a second ORDINAL issue I would like to raise. We are discussing coherence here. Many speakers have cited examples of the extent to which the various policies are not coherent. In my view however the development policy itself needs to be more coherent too. There is no coherence because there is still no effective coordination with the Member States and there are some projects being carried out by the Member States and the European Union ORG in the developing countries which are very much at odds with one another. Nor is there coherence vis vis the European NORP taxpayer when we draft a development policy which is accommodated in the Union s budget but the EDF ORG remains outside it. Mr President in Office of the Council ORG if in future you succeed in making this EUR 13.5 billion LAW subject to the supervision of the parliamentary Committee on Budgetary Control ORG and to bodies such as OLAF ORG then I believe you will raise the level of acceptability. This to my mind is also something that we should call upon the Intergovernmental Conference to do i.e. establish the EDF ORG firmly in the budget of the European Union ORG . SPEAKER ID 32 LANGUAGE FR NAME Co teaux Mr President we certainly must concede that on balance this text is full of good intentions but we did not vote in favour of it in committee nor shall we do so in plenary. We had two CARDINAL reasons for this both of which gave rise to amendments which I should like to explain here very briefly. P First the Committee on Development and Cooperation ORG advocates the communitisation of the EDF ORG clearly that is misguided. In our view cooperation is and should remain an intergovernmental exercise. With Europe LOC preparing to enlarge communitising the EDF ORG would make it easy to hide a lack of commitment behind the screen of the Community ORG budget quite apart from the fact that we would be wasting a fruitful and promising opportunity of associating our southern partners with our cooperation policy. Lastly the Commission has in the recent past had trouble managing the funds for development and humanitarian aid transparently as Mrs Maes PERSON has just reminded us so opportunely. Why should we add to them? P Secondly ORDINAL we find it most regrettable that Mr Corrie s PRODUCT report should mention the trade and development agreement with South Africa GPE because in the final analysis this report is typical of the amateur diplomacy to which the European Commission ORG is taking ever more frequent recourse. It is perfectly astounding that the Union could have negotiated an agreement on behalf of the Member States in which a fundamental section is quite simply left blank. And let me say in passing it is even more astonishing that the Council ORG allowed it to. P As a result we are now in the absurd position of negotiating from a position of weakness on vital aspects such as wine and agricultural production within the framework of an agreement which we have already signed. The part of this agreement which blocks negotiations could mean that the Union ends up paying producers to stop producing sherry port and a whole host of products which are purely and simply copies under international commercial law. Imagine the potential cost of such a precedent. P It is proof as if we still needed it of the fact that immature diplomacy which defends no interests unless of course they are individual interests and is caught between the dogma of free trade and pressure groups and more or less friendly NGOs is not just inefficient it is positively dangerous. P Finally a word on the general thinking behind the Corrie PRODUCT report. Nowadays let us face it the Joint Assembly ORG is seen as an obstacle to free international trade by the dogmatisers in Geneva GPE and Washington GPE . It was a chance to reiterate that our original and exemplary mode of cooperation with the southern countries should be developed and strengthened. The Corrie PRODUCT report missed this chance and we must regrettably punish it for losing so much. SPEAKER ID 33 LANGUAGE PT NAME Amado . PT Mr President by way of both a conclusion and a summary I would like to highlight three CARDINAL key aspects of this debate. First ORDINAL of all many speakers stressed that globalisation accentuates regional imbalances and social inequality and increases poverty. This suggests that something must be done failing which tensions will be aggravated and conflicts jeopardising international peace and stability will arise or worsen. Secondly ORDINAL it will be important to approach development policies from a different angle in this context taking advantage of their capacity for correcting imbalances and reducing inequality. I believe that the importance that everyone has attached to the European Union s role in international development policies is significant. Everyone recognises indeed this was the theme of today DATE s debate that if the European Union ORG is to play a more active and leading role in development policies at world level it will have no choice but to enhance the coherence of its own various development related policies. I note that some speakers also emphasised that responsibility for coherence in EU ORG policies is not a matter for the Council for the Commission ORG or for Parliament ORG alone. Quite the contrary it will have to be the subject of a concerted effort in terms of discussion and legislative and institutional preparation be it on the part of the Commission or of the Council ORG or even on the part of the European Parliament ORG itself and some Members have in fact already suggested that a monitoring centre or a working party could be established to monitor the impact of various policies in the specific area of development. P Finally I would like to emphasise that it is also important and this is one of the priorities of the Portuguese NORP Presidency s programme to note the view that it is necessary to recognise the value of development in the European Union s policies and in particular in the context of its foreign policy. We believe that this is absolutely vital failing which we will be unable to take any consistent action as regards the coherence of policies and we cannot do this without giving development policies their rightful place as an instrument for upholding the principles and values underpinning Europe LOC s status in the international system. For this reason it may be necessary as I have stressed to change the model and move away from the post colonial model towards a more European NORP approach to development policies. In this respect I believe and some speakers here have also commented on this that the adoption of the new convention which succeeds the Lom Convention EVENT is an important instrument of renewal and represents a new approach to a partnership with such an important group of countries from the south at a time of considerable instability in the international negotiating process as demonstrated by the first ORDINAL negotiating round in Seattle GPE . SPEAKER ID 34 CARDINAL NAME Nielson PERSON . I sense some degree of frustration in many of the contributions to this debate. I have given you a statement on behalf of the Commission which I think provides a useful background to this discussion. We will furnish more detailed material relating directly to all the issues concerning coherence. This discussion is not new. We are currently working on it in the Commission and when that work is done I will report on it as many have been asking if it will be possible to see the report on coherence. P I have no doubt that as a result of the increasing political attention attached to these problems something which has clearly been reflected in the debate today it will be easier for the Commission and the DG on Development to bring coherence to the forefront of our working agenda. This also calls for the introduction of further new mechanisms in the Commission system which may very well include as suggested by some of the political groups in Parliament ORG the setting up of a special intra service working group and the establishment of a kind of coherence watch in the Commission. P I have read and heard in the debate that coherence is being used as some kind of a miracle formula that takes care of everything. I think it is important to keep it as a relatively clearly defined discipline of trying to reduce inconsistencies where they really exist and we certainly do have them. Much of this has to do with real disagreement between sector interests in each and every Member State as has been very honestly said here in this House ORG people more or less identify with their spheres of interest and all this is legitimate. I would however warn against the illusion that incoherence is the product of some kind of a mechanical deficiency in the system. This exists but it is only a small part of what we are discussing. The major part of it has to do with well known established differences of interest between sexes and so on and this is the problem. P Mr Mulder PERSON mentioned that no farmer will start producing anything if the price is too low. This is true in our part of the world but our partners and beneficiaries in Africa LOC have a slightly different perspective. They farm not just for a living but in order to live and this makes a difference. Subsistence farming is not based on price calculations it is based on the hope of rain in the next season DATE . This does not apply to all farming in developing countries but to the poverty focusing which we need to deliver better than so far. From that perspective what I am saying here is of deep relevance. P Other issues have been mentioned cattle farming in Namibia GPE tomatoes and milk powder in the Caribbean LOC . We should not be too masochistic. There is a limit to how useful that is. All these cases are characterised by the fact that they have been taken care of. The intervention prices have been regulated and the problems we had with beef in Western Africa GPE and in Namibia GPE were actually solved by reducing the intervention support. These are real problems but they have all been dealt with. P As regards the issue of cacao GPE chocolate I repeat that the 5 has to do with creating a basis for a living in the neighbouring countries. What we are talking about here are the local nuts which are as important to the people collecting them and making a living out of them in Burkina Faso LOC as coconuts for farmers in Ghana GPE . This is not a clear case of incoherence it is more a case of a competition between suppliers. P What was mentioned concerning sugar in the Caribbean LOC is more complicated. In the Overseas Countries and Territories Framework the accumulation of some of these trade aspects represents a complicated problem but it may be that what we are talking about here has more to do with promoting the interests of some European NORP companies than with generating income in the Caribbean LOC . In any case this is a matter which we are currently dealing with. P I am committed to try to create a balance in all these issues and I would mention the achievement of the trade development and cooperation agreement with South Africa GPE . In all modesty I would claim that this is something that documents that the Commission is willing to walk or fly the extra mile in order to ensure coherence between the perspective of development cooperation and the perspective of trade interests. We certainly have done our share to solve that problem and I sincerely hope that we now will have a soft landing and a peaceful implementation in the forthcoming years DATE of that agreement. P Finally I thank you again for this debate. We will come back again with material on these issues because these problems in one CARDINAL way or another are here to stay simply because development cooperation represents basically doing something in the world that is different from taking care of traditionally defined trade interests etc. We have to reconcile those different approaches. SPEAKER ID 35 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you very much Commissioner Nielson PERSON . P I have received eight CARDINAL motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 37 2 of the Rules of Procedure. P The debate is closed. P The vote will take place on Thursday DATE at 12.00 p.m. MONEY CHAPTER ID LAW 3 Next session of UN Human Rights Commission ORG SPEAKER ID 36 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is the statement by the Council ORG on EU ORG priorities for the next session of the UN Human Rights Commission ORG on 20 March 2000 DATE . SPEAKER ID 37 LANGUAGE PT NAME Amado Mr President ladies and gentlemen as you know the European Union ORG played an active role in the 55th ORDINAL session of the Human Rights Commission ORG held in Geneva GPE in March DATE and April 1999 DATE . It tabled resolutions on the human rights situation in Iran GPE Iraq GPE in the Israeli NORP settlements in Burma GPE Myanmar GPE in the Democratic Republic of the GPE Congo GPE and in Sudan GPE and negotiated statements to be issued on behalf of the chairman on Colombia GPE and on East Timor GPE . P For the first ORDINAL time the European Union ORG tabled a resolution on the death penalty which was enormously successful and led work on a resolution concerning children s rights which was a joint initiative with the Latin American NORP group of countries. The Union will continue to play this role at the 56th ORDINAL session of the Human Rights Commission ORG to be held in Geneva GPE in March DATE and April DATE . In particular as agreed at the Human Rights Council Group ORG on 9 February 2000 DATE the European Union ORG intends to table draft resolutions on the Israeli NORP settlements Iran GPE Iraq GPE Sudan GPE the Democratic Republic of the GPE Congo GPE Burma GPE Myanmar GPE a draft chairman s statement on Colombia GPE and possibly on East Timor GPE together with a draft statement on the situation in various countries. P The European Union ORG will continue discussions on preparations for the 56th ORDINAL session of the Human Rights Commission ORG at the next meeting of the Human Rights Group ORG in March DATE . In particular there will be a discussion of the possibility of tabling a draft resolution on the death penalty. To date the group has not reached agreement on the strategy to be adopted in this respect and in particular with regard to formulating a compromise to be tabled in the last resort in case of any amendments to the contrary including Article 2 7 LAW of the Charter of the United Nations which refers to sovereignty. We have tried to reach agreement in advance on a compromise text in view of the difficulties that arose at the 1999 DATE session of the Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly ORG at which the Member States failed to agree on an amendment introducing a reference to Article 2 7 LAW into the draft resolution sponsored by the European Union ORG on the death penalty. P As you know at the 55th ORDINAL session of the Human Rights Commission ORG held last year DATE the United States GPE decided at a very late stage to table a draft resolution on China GPE . This draft resolution was defeated by a Chinese NORP no action motion. The European Union ORG voted against that motion. The European Union ORG s position on the approach to be adopted towards China GPE in the Human Rights Commission ORG was confirmed at the General Affairs Council ORG on 21 March 1999 DATE there was no European Union ORG initiative on China GPE nor was agreement reached to co sponsor a resolution on China GPE but an EU ORG vote against the no action motion. It is by no means certain that the European Union ORG could have maintained a united front if this resolution had been put to the vote. P The United States of America GPE will be tabling a draft resolution on China GPE at the 56th ORDINAL session of the Human Rights Commission ORG and are putting pressure on the European Union ORG to support this draft resolution. This initiative has provoked a strong reaction on China GPE s part the Chinese NORP authorities are making representations to the countries and institutions of the European Union ORG in an attempt to persuade them not to support the United States GPE initiative. This initiative is being discussed within the Union but with no hope of a decision in the near future. It is in the interests of the European Union ORG to keep all its options open for as long as possible and in any case at least until after the EU ORG China GPE human rights dialogue meeting is held on 25 February 2000 DATE . In view of changes made to the membership of the Human Rights Commission ORG we estimate the vote on the no action motion will be close. P It is therefore important this year DATE too that the countries of the European Union ORG should reach a consensus on the position to take in any vote on the resolution. In this context it is important to note that the European Union ORG regularly opposes requests by China GPE that the human rights dialogue should automatically rule out tabling a resolution at the Human Rights Commission ORG in Geneva GPE . The European Union ORG unequivocally considers that although it is a very valuable instrument for exchanging views and for taking note of the overall position of the other party the dialogue should also yield concrete results on the ground and when this does not happen it may be necessary to present a resolution to the Human Rights Commission ORG potentially whilst the dialogue is continuing. The European Union ORG also regularly informs China GPE that the Human Rights Commission ORG is the appropriate body for considering human rights issues and whether or not it agrees with this initiative this is in any case legitimate from this point of view. P The next human rights dialogue will take place on 25 February DATE in Lisbon GPE and will include seminars on legal issues and on women s rights and it is expected that representatives from the academic world and from civil society will take part. The next human rights seminar will be organised by the Portuguese NORP Presidency in May 2000 DATE and during the last round of the dialogue in October 1999 DATE the Chinese NORP side accepted the European Union s proposal for technical assistance to support the process of ratifying the United Nations International Pact on Economic Social and Cultural Rights and the United Nations International Pact on Civil and Political Rights ORG both of which have been signed by the Chinese Government ORG . P The European Union ORG is discussing issues on which it hopes that China GPE will take concrete measures and on the basis of these discussions the presidency will convey to the Chinese NORP authorities the message that the European Union ORG hopes China GPE will announce positive measures at the session on 25 February DATE . The presidency will also present to the Chinese NORP authorities a list of individual cases on which it intends to express its serious concern. The meeting held in Beijing GPE in October 1999 DATE confirmed that on the one hand the Chinese NORP authorities were willing to make concessions on issues relating to the dialogue itself with a restructuring of the dialogue and of discussion of legal forms of repression such as the death penalty and administrative detention. On the other hand they will not give any ground on the pivotal questions of the single party system and territorial integrity. P Discussions within the European Union ORG about the situation in China GPE following the outcome of the dialogue rounds in 1999 DATE have led the European Union ORG to decide to express its concern about human rights violations in China GPE more firmly the same applies to the absence of concrete outcomes from the dialogue while recognising the positive steps that China GPE has made on the international stage. On various occasions the European Union ORG has reiterated to the Chinese NORP authorities its disappointment with the results of the dialogue and has stressed that it hoped for better outcomes in certain more sensitive areas. It was decided that the dialogue should continue but in a more targeted and effective way given that China GPE has agreed with the European Union ORG s proposal to restructure the dialogue by means of better use of experts and to establish a closer link with the seminars. P Lastly during the next Human Rights Commission there will also be a debate on rationalising the work of the Commission ORG itself. A working party has been set up with the express task of revising the Commission ORG s mechanisms. This working party has worked hard to reach agreement that it is essential to enhance the effectiveness of the present mechanisms and to make them more rigorous especially in the financial field. The European Union ORG will oppose any spurious attempt to use this reform of the Human Rights Commission ORG s activities to limit its capacity for intervention by restricting its sphere of influence and its ongoing monitoring of all human rights issues at world level. SPEAKER ID 38 NAME Patten . Mr President I would like to thank the presidency for the work it has done to prepare for Geneva GPE on subjects like racism civil and political rights and the right to development. As the presidency said much remains to be done despite the understandable request by Parliament ORG and many NGOs that the European Union ORG should set out its position well in advance of the Geneva GPE session. That is easier said than done we are still discussing some of the toughest issues. For example discussion is taking place about many of the matters raised in Parliament ORG s resolution and it is too early to predict the outcome in all cases. P It is not surprising that the debate is long and difficult. That does not suggest any lack of commitment to the improvement of human rights but it does indicate the usual concern to get our approach right so that we really make a difference. However let me reflect that concern by referring to three CARDINAL controversial issues the death penalty Cuba GPE and China GPE . I am going to be so unwise as to allow one CARDINAL or two CARDINAL personal reflections to creep into my remarks. P We are currently reviewing the options and possibilities for introducing a death penalty resolution in the Human Rights Commission ORG . This has always been a subject about which I personally have felt extremely strongly I have always voted against the death penalty. Spurred on by Amnesty International ORG and others one of the first ORDINAL decisions I took as Governor of Hong Kong GPE was to abolish the death penalty. We know what happened recently at the UN General Assembly ORG . We had to freeze our resolution on the death penalty or risk the passing of a resolution that would have incorporated wholly unacceptable arguments that asserted that human rights are not universally applicable and valid. P The New York GPE stage is different from Geneva GPE . Last year DATE s debate in New York GPE on sovereignty and humanitarian intervention was such a sensitive topic that it influenced all other issues. It certainly influenced the debate on the moratorium on the death penalty. The debate in Geneva GPE however is more focused on human rights issues. We may therefore stand a better chance of making progress there. P Secondly Cuba. I want to address this issue directly because we in Europe LOC are criticised unfairly for not taking human rights there sufficiently seriously. We are extremely concerned about moves by the Cuban NORP Government over the last year DATE that have further curtailed public freedom moves like changes in the penal code and the scope of the death penalty. We are also worried by the recent increase in the number of political detentions. We are monitoring the human rights situation through the reports of NGOs and the work of our human rights working group based in the EU ORG embassies in Havana GPE . We have regularly put our criticisms to the Cuban NORP authorities and this Parliament ORG has done the same. But I do not believe that the right approach is to try to isolate Cuba GPE . We want a fair and open society in Cuba GPE a Cuba GPE which respects the principles of the market the sanctity of contract and the rule of law. We want to encourage a process of transition to democracy and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. P My views are exactly the same when it comes to the third ORDINAL subject with which I wish to deal namely China GPE . Quite simply I want us to be engaged with China GPE . It would be self indulgent and self defeating as well as insulting to over a fifth of humanity to want anything else. I also want to see a China GPE transformed by peaceful change into a free pluralist society which does not lock up democracy activists or religious believers. P So what should we do? Naturally we should trade enthusiastically with China GPE and hope that we can welcome China GPE into the World Trade Organisation ORG on sensible terms. It is a misnomer to talk about a World Trade Organisation ORG which does not include China GPE or Russia GPE for that matter. But I do not believe today nor have I ever believed that our burgeoning economic relationship with China GPE manifested for example by China GPE s EUR 25 billion surplus with the European Union ORG should silence us when it comes to China GPE s human rights record. For me the question is not whether we should address the question of human rights in China GPE we have a duty to do so and a legitimate interest in doing so but rather what is the most effective way of doing this? P So what should be our attitude towards a Geneva resolution this year DATE ? As the presidency has noted the Union as a whole is considering its position. But I strongly suggest there are a number of factors of which the Member States ought to take proper account. First ORDINAL while some people question whether tabling a Geneva resolution makes any difference several of the most distinguished Chinese NORP advocates of democracy strongly believe that it is a valuable move not least because of the message it sends to people in China GPE itself. That is a point that deserves serious consideration. P Secondly ORDINAL we will all want to take proper account of what has actually been happening in China GPE in recent months DATE for instance the heavy sentences imposed on democracy campaigners the detention and recent punishments meted out to members of Christian NORP churches and the arrests and sentences of the members of Falun Gong PERSON . Chinese NORP leaders are in no doubt about our position on all these issues and on developments in Tibet GPE . We have made our views very clear to them. While we all know that for many people in China GPE there has been a real long term improvement in their economic prospects and their social and economic liberties there is a dark side to the picture as well. Critics of tabling a resolution say that at least we now have a human rights dialogue with China GPE . That is true and potentially valuable although I have to say and I have said to Chinese NORP officials as has the presidency that there has not been nearly as much content to our dialogue as we would have liked. Of course the dialogue has enabled us to identify and implement EU ORG cooperation programmes in the human rights and legal spheres. That is very welcome and I also believe that our village governance programme should help to promote democracy at grassroots level. Naturally any dialogue as complex as the one on human rights is going to be a long term process but I wish I could point to more real gains. P The next dialogue in Lisbon GPE on 25 February DATE will be an important test. It will show whether the dialogue is producing results or not. What finally do we want to see as the first ORDINAL steps? Well for example we would like to see China GPE move from signing the UN Conventions on Civil and Political Rights LAW and on Social and Cultural Rights toward actually ratifying them. I wish we were closer to that. P Where does all that leave us this year DATE ? I repeat that Member States will have to make up their minds. What I hope is first that we in Europe LOC will adopt a common position and stick to it that we will not allow some to be picked off that our position will not be based on self delusion or pretence that it will be a common position and a sensible position. P I know that some people say we must have a better way of pressing our concern about human rights than through tabling resolutions. But if that is true then at the very least we need to be more imaginative and honest with ourselves in looking for that way forward. If we are to rest our position on the human rights dialogue then we need to be able to convince you the NGO community and the public at large that it is actually getting somewhere. That in my judgement is the challenge for the next few weeks DATE . I am grateful to the House ORG for its concern about human rights around the world and particularly in China GPE . P SPEAKER ID 39 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you very much Commissioner Patten PERSON . P We will now interrupt the debate on the joint statement concerning the next session of the UN Human Rights Commission ORG and proceed to the vote. That concludes the vote P EXPLANATIONS OF VOTE Lienemann report A5 0014 2000 SPEAKER ID 51 CARDINAL LANGUAGE FR NAME Caudron . FR PERSON I welcome the quality and the ambition of this report on LIFE. I shall briefly remind you that LIFE is a financial instrument used to support environmental policies within the European Union ORG and also in third ORDINAL countries whether they be neighbouring countries around the Mediterranean LOC countries around the Baltic Sea LOC or applicant countries. P The Committee on the Environment Public Health ORG and Consumer Protection ORG has proposed many amendments which have for the most part been retained in the common position adopted by the Council ORG . P As far as the third ORDINAL phase of LIFE 2000 2004 DATE is concerned the instrument is to be divided into three CARDINAL sections LIFE Nature 47 of the resources LIFE Environment 47 and LIFE Third Countries ORG 6 . In my opinion the most important amendments concern the following P LIFE s contribution to sustainable development within the Community ORG and also to the development of Community ORG policy in the field of the environment particularly regarding the integration of the environment into other policies as well as to the implementation and updating of legislation relating to the environment P Improving the efficiency transparency and methodology of procedures for the implementation of LIFE procedures for information and the dissemination of such information to the public and procedures for cooperation between recipients P The objectives of LIFE this must have as its main objective sustainable urban development in close association with the pilot projects carried out under the URBAN ORG initiative on which I have had the opportunity to speak elsewhere P The contribution that the projects supported by LIFE make to the sustainability of social and economic activities and thus job creation. P I consider it crucial that the LIFE instrument should remain open to the participation of candidate countries from central and eastern Europe LOC . The other candidate countries e.g. Cyprus Turkey Malta ORG my also take part in LIFE when agreements permitting such participation are signed with these countries. P The stumbling block in the negotiations with the Council ORG lies of course in the amount of the total appropriation allocated for the third ORDINAL phase of the LIFE programme 2000 2004 DATE . The Commission proposal ratified by the Council ORG is for EUR 613 million CARDINAL whilst the Committee on the Environment Public Health ORG and Consumer Protection considers that the budget should be EUR 850 million. I support Mrs Lienemann PERSON s firm stance. The financial allocation has not in fact been upgraded since the programme was created even when the membership of the EC ORG was increased to fifteen CARDINAL Member States following enlargement. If the report is adopted in plenary session then conciliation proceedings will have to be opened in accordance with the codecision procedure in order to solve the problem of the amount of appropriations earmarked for the programme. This type of procedure is common practice since the programmes or legislative measures are too often allocated budgets which do not live up to their ambitions! P B ge report A5 0023 2000 SPEAKER ID 52 LANGUAGE FR NAME Caudron . FR PERSON As an MEP ORG and more importantly as a consumer I welcome the European Commission ORG s proposal as a step in the direction of enhanced food safety within the European Union ORG . P This proposal has two CARDINAL objectives first ORDINAL to amend the 1991 DATE Council Directive EVENT on animal health conditions by removing the provisions on scrapie and secondly ORDINAL to introduce a new regulation establishing rules for preventing and combating transmissible spongiform encephalopathies TSE ORG or BSE ORG type diseases affecting sheep and other animal species. P What is interesting abut this new legislation is that a specific legal basis is being created in order to combat scrapie. What is even more satisfactory is that this was one of our main demands in our follow up report on the mad cow crisis. P I also consider it essential for the sake of coherence that existing legislation on scrapie which is limited to the trade in ovine and caprine animals should be incorporated in a single and complete set of new rules on TSE ORG affecting all animals throughout the European Union ORG rules designed to prevent the consumption of foodstuffs or feedingstuffs. P These rules are all the more welcome in that doubts still persist as regards scrapie. A number of scientific hypotheses maintain that scrapie developed into BSE ORG in cows and therefore caused the BSE ORG epidemic. Even if this proposal for a European Parliament ORG and Council ORG regulation to prevent and combat certain TSE ORG needs to be made more accurate and more effective especially as regards detecting and fighting scrapie it is still a notable improvement. It is a pledge to European NORP citizens who have voiced their concern as regards European NORP food policy on many occasions. P The European Parliament ORG has relayed their concerns and they have been heard. As a result of the debates on the principle of precaution traceability responsibility and transparency the European Commission ORG has presented a White Paper ORG on food safety. This White Paper ORG sets out several areas of concern and proposes the creation of an independent European Food Authority ORG as part of a European NORP strategy to restore consumer confidence. It is up to us as responsible Europeans NORP to prove that the single market and the free movement of goods and food safety are not mutually exclusive. P Cederschi ld report A5 0008 2000 DATE SPEAKER ID 53 LANGUAGE IT NAME Fatuzzo Mr President I voted for this initiative to amend the copyright legislation because I believe it is one of the most important sectors within the remit of the European Parliament ORG . P In my view products of the mind are far more valuable than tangible products namely those that can be seen and touched. The fruits of the intellect and science which are intangible are of inestimable importance. Therefore the European Community ORG should be more energetic in providing practical encouragement not just through upholding patents but through concessions and other forms of support for scientists who are striving through the knowledge and experience they have acquired to give future generations something better than that which they have today DATE . We are nonetheless aware that we are concerned here with a sharing of powers between the Member States and the Community ORG . At the same time we appreciate the fact that the WIPO treaties are a significant step forward in the direction of guaranteeing the rights of distributors and practising artists. We are therefore voting in favour of the recommendation. SPEAKER ID 55 LANGUAGE DE NAME Schr der Ilka DE ORG The Group of the Greens European Free Alliance ORG abstained from the vote on this matter because in the plenary debate of the previous day DATE Commissioner Bolkestein PERSON did not respond to any of my questions regarding EU ORG accession to the WIPO Treaties. P In institutional terms there has been no clarification of what role the EP ORG is to play in the further development of the WIPO Treaties. In addition there is a clear tendency in matters of international jurisdiction more and more often to obtain a pure EU ORG jurisdiction. When it is then still not clear to what extent the EP ORG can participate in the decision making processes the question of legitimacy arises. Moreover the concept of author is not defined in the Treaties. In this regard too the Commission has not answered the question as to what definition it wishes to base its discussions on and whether it wishes to settle foreseeable conflicts by imposing its own definition of the law on others. One CARDINAL of the trickiest aspects is the public interest will ratifying and applying WIPO lead to the privatisation of culture? P And finally the matter of the relationship between TRIPs and WIPO must be clarified. Regarding this too there has been only silence by way of a response from the Commission. P If nothing helpful is forthcoming in the course of a parliamentary debate planned for clarification and orientation then we must at least abstain from voting. P Graefe zu Baringdorf A5 0015 2000 SPEAKER ID 56 LANGUAGE PT NAME Figueiredo GPE . PT Food safety issues are in the spotlight following the BSE ORG and dioxin scandals. GMOs are still the subject of great uncertainty both in terms of their environmental impact and of their effects on human and animal health. The precautionary principle must therefore apply in the absence of scientific certainty. P The use of biotechnology needs to be studied in greater depth and not just packaged for immediate sale to boost the profits of a few multinationals in this sector. The profit motive is very much behind the present food safety crises. P This is the context that the rapporteur finds himself working in making a legal link between the issue of GMOs and feedingstuffs and noting that the latter shall be authorised only if ... safe for human health and the environment . Furthermore he considers that genetically modified additives shall be clearly identified as such on any label or any document official or otherwise which is affixed to or accompanies the additive . This will facilitate greater control and traceability of such additives and guarantee the consumer s freedom of choice. P In view of the Montreal Protocol LAW on Genetically Modified Organisms GMOs I welcome the fact that the rapporteur has included these issues in his report and I have therefore voted in favour of it. P Stenzel report A5 0034 2000 SPEAKER ID 57 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL NAME Pronk Mr President I would very briefly like to give an explanation of vote on behalf of the PPE Group ORG on the EQUAL ORG report. We have followed a nominal list which was identical to that which we had agreed upon beforehand with the Socialist Group ORG . The Socialist Group ORG has now changed its mind and this is why the report is not as clear as it would have been. This is why we are abstaining. We want to ensure that the EQUAL ORG report which is very important for refugees the elderly the handicapped and women simply goes ahead. It is regrettable that due to the procedure the report has received such unfavourable attention in this plenary session. I am convinced that the rapporteur s nationality has played a certain role which should not be of relevance in this Parliament ORG . This is actually in conflict with European NORP values and certainly with the parliamentary values which are referred to so often in this Parliament ORG . These were our reasons for abstaining from the vote on this report. We want EQUAL to go ahead. We assent to the main thrust of it but we deplore the procedure and especially the fact that some groups have exploited this procedure to their advantage.
