SPEAKER ID 135 CARDINAL LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da PERSON Costa Mr Medina Ortega PERSON I naturally share your concerns and I can assure you that a coastal country like my own the country currently holding the presidency is naturally very concerned about this issue all the more so as it does not have any oil tankers of its own. P However we have to work within the existing legislative framework. That legislative framework is the 1995 DATE directive which has a set of regulations with a degree of flexibility which should perhaps be implemented more rigorously. In this area we have to work with the world as it is and that means reacting in accordance with the facts of the situation. In view of the seriousness of such situations we can congratulate ourselves on the fact that the authorities have at least reacted and undertaken to examine the legislative provisions already existing in this field. The Commission s intentions in this area are positive as it intends to reinforce the application of the 1995 DATE directive. The Council ORG is minded to give priority to this area within the Transport Council ORG and we intend to follow this up as quickly as possible. We also hope that the European Parliament ORG will be able to examine this issue with equal promptness when it comes before this House ORG under the codecision procedure. SPEAKER ID 136 CARDINAL NAME Korhola ORG Mr President in Kotka GPE in Finland GPE there is currently a vessel carrying chemicals which is sailing under a flag of convenience. The vessel is anchored outside the port as the condition it is in is a safety hazard for the port and the surrounding areas and because it cannot be inspected properly as there is no one who will pay. Would it be possible for the EU ORG to create a standardised inspection system that would also guarantee payment out of Community funds for the inspection of ships that fly a flag of convenience and cannot themselves pay the cost? SPEAKER ID 137 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PT PERSON Mrs Korhola ORG as you will understand I do not at the moment have the information I need to give you a concrete reply. The information that I have is to do with the 1995 DATE directive which does not include any provisions of that kind. However the Council ORG will certainly let you have a concrete reply on the options available for acting in the case you have mentioned. SPEAKER ID 138 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 139 CARDINAL NAME Anna Karamanou PERSON Question No 2 by H 0024 00 ORG P Subject High infant mortality levels in Kosovo GPE According to the most recent UN ORG information forwarded to the World Health Organisation Kosovo ORG has the highest rate of infant mortality in Europe LOC . About 50 CARDINAL of premature babies do not survive and the war has resulted in a massive increase in the number of miscarriages. Even babies born when due tend to be underdeveloped. In view of the humanitarian aid being given by the European Union ORG and the efforts being made by the head of the interim administration Mr Bernard Kouchner PERSON what measures will the Council ORG take to defend the rights of the women of Kosovo GPE to motherhood and to protect the health of pregnant women women in confinement and new born children? SPEAKER ID 140 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON Mr President Mrs Karamanou PERSON s question is an extremely serious one and I would not wish to conceal that fact. We are perfectly aware of the difficult and dramatic humanitarian situation in Kosovo GPE and of the problem of displaced people in that region and I mean people who originate from Kosovo GPE and of the particular effect of this on child health and on mortality rates. P I think it is well known that the European Union ORG has made a clear contribution to the humanitarian aid effort being made by the international community. As you know the European Community ORG has contributed a total of EUR 378 million MONEY for the province of Kosovo GPE alone and this has to be seen in conjunction with the contributions made by Member States at national level. P This contribution covers various projects in the fields of health and health systems and of water purification. Furthermore as you know the European Union ORG makes a contribution to the United Nations High Commission for Refugees ORG which came to EUR 66.3 million MONEY in 1999 DATE . I think that Mrs Karamanou PERSON is aware that because of the need for division of labour between the international donors the task of restoring health care in Kosovo GPE has been entrusted to the World Health Organisation ORG . The reports produced by the WHO ORG indicate that it is fully aware of the alarming infant mortality situation and it has focused its efforts on improving basic conditions in maternity and general hospitals. P Nevertheless we are aware that this situation is far from a satisfactory solution and that there are widespread repercussions in other areas of health care apart from child health. This is not just a technical situation it is a political situation and it goes hand in hand with the need to solve the political situation because there are aspects to this and we may as well be open about this which are associated with the international community s inability up to now to make a multi ethnic society function in Kosovo GPE with tragic effects on attempts to improve health care in that region. SPEAKER ID 141 LANGUAGE EL NAME Karamanou Mr President in Office of the Council ORG I thank you for your answer which supplements what Commissioner Patten PERSON said yesterday DATE on the subject. Yet the sum of EUR 378 million CARDINAL you mentioned had been given in 1999 DATE was proved by the facts to be quite insufficient to create even rudimentary civilised conditions in Kosovo GPE especially where the provision of health services is concerned. P Mr President in Office do you not think that the very fact of increased child mortality is an abomination for the continent of Europe LOC a shameful thing which should motivate us all so that the aid we provide becomes more effective and more generous? P Of course the situation was not idyllic even before the bombardments anything but I should say. However since NATO ORG s intervention there has been a very clear deterioration in the natural and human environment. So Mr President in Office of the Council ORG is it not a moral obligation that we should try to create civilised conditions for the long suffering inhabitants of Kosovo GPE and above all keep our promises to them? SPEAKER ID 142 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da PERSON Costa Mrs Karamanou I recognise the fact that all the efforts that have been made in Kosovo GPE in this field have not been enough. I do not think that any of us has the least doubt about that. I do not want to link this question with your comments about the period before and after NATO ORG s intervention as we will probably touch on that issue at another point during this Question Time LOC . Nevertheless I would like to say that the European Union ORG is aware that the resources it has devoted to Kosovo GPE reflect the financial limitations it has to work within. We have to remember that we share responsibility in that region with the international community. The European Union ORG has a certain responsibility in view of that particular role but we cannot undertake to rapidly rebuild structures that were as you have said yourself Mrs Karamanou PERSON not the best before the military action in Kosovo GPE . P What is more I do not believe Mrs Karamanou that the military action in Kosovo GPE resulted in such a significant destruction of public health facilities as to have had a direct impact on the current situation. The present position is more dramatic in terms of displaced populations and in terms of a whole raft of economic factors and of the level of satisfaction with basic health facilities resulting from the overall breakdown in organisational structures in Kosovo GPE s administration. This is the basic issue underlying the present situation as a whole. And if we cannot solve the political problem which must be done in accordance with the relevant United Nations ORG resolution then we will not solve the problem of child health nor the various other problems faced by this region. SPEAKER ID 143 LANGUAGE NL ORG NAME Staes PERSON I would like to widen the debate and include the situation in Mitrovica GPE . In cooperation with Europe LOC the international community rebuilt the hospital there too but it is located in the northern part of the city thus prohibiting access to Albanian Kosovars LOC . P This means that medical aid is still denied to the Albanian Kosovars LOC . This is also happening elsewhere in the country causing tension between the Albanian Kosovars LOC and Serbs NORP making for a situation where nobody trusts anybody anymore and where Albanians NORP do not want to be looked after by Serbs NORP and vice versa. P I understand very well what you are saying and you are right the European Union ORG should work in a wider context of international cooperation. But where will you place the emphasis? What will you do to ensure that Albanian NORP Kosovars too can be cared for in a hospital including that in Mitrovica GPE ? SPEAKER ID 144 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON Mr Staes the situation in Mitrovica GPE is well known. This is a very special situation with a degree of inter ethnic tension which fortunately is not matched with such severity in others parts of Kosovo GPE . P I perfectly understand Mr Staes PRODUCT s concerns. Nevertheless I would like to say that Bernard Kouchner PERSON s work in this area has aimed to comply with the objectives of the relevant United Nations ORG resolution in an attempt to create multi ethnic facilities which can serve the various communities including the various aspects of the administration. I believe that we should not jump to conclusions here about who is responsible because there are various protagonists involved. The situation in Mitrovica GPE is appalling and involves very special tensions and I believe that the measures taken over the last few hours TIME to create safe conditions in that area are to be welcomed. Nevertheless I have to say that regrettably we do not have the police resources and this is connected with the Member States contributions to guarantee the follow up action we proposed to the military action that is to say the establishment of inter ethnic coordination mechanisms guaranteeing adequate safety for the various communities and in particular access to hospitals. SPEAKER ID 145 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 146 CARDINAL NAME Alexandros Alavanos Question No 3 by H 0027 00 DATE P Subject Indictment of NATO before War Crimes Tribunal Human rights organisations such as the US GPE Human Rights Watch have already collected significant evidence of NATO ORG crimes in connection with the bombing of Kosovo GPE and Serbia GPE with a view to bringing a case before the War Crimes Tribunal ORG in The Hague GPE . On the basis of this evidence some of which has already been lodged with the Tribunal NATO ORG is accused of serious violations of international humanitarian law and wilful murder . P Does the Council ORG consider that such accusations should be put before the War Crimes Tribunal ORG for a thorough judicial investigation? In the event of a judicial inquiry into the accusations against NATO ORG what will be done in respect of the High Representative for the CFSP who was NATO ORG Secretary General during the crisis? Is there any procedure for suspending him from office until the judicial investigation into the accusations has been completed? SPEAKER ID 147 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON Mr President Mr Alavanos question naturally gives us food for thought on a wide range of issues. The Council ORG has already on various occasions stated its conviction that the severe measures taken by NATO ORG were both necessary and justified to deal with extremist and irresponsible actions involving clear violations of the United Nations Security Council ORG resolutions. I am aware that there may be different views about NATO ORG s action and the legitimacy of that action. Everyone is free to hold such views. In my own country the various parliamentary groups had differing views on this matter. That was how it was. P In any case the Council ORG s position is clear in that it considers that the objective of the air campaign carried out by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation ORG in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia GPE was to put an end to the humanitarian disaster in Kosovo GPE caused by the Belgrade GPE regime. This objective was fully and formally expressed in the statement adopted by the General Affairs Council ORG in Luxembourg GPE on 8 April DATE . I must say that these NATO ORG measures were not taken lightly and were only carried out as a last resort when it became evident that all avenues for reaching a negotiated solution had been exhausted and that the Belgrade GPE authorities were concentrating their forces in order to expel the Kosovo Albanians from EVENT their land. I am sure you are aware Mr Alavanos that during her recent visit to NATO ORG headquarters Prosecutor Del Ponte PERSON stressed that the International Tribunal ORG was obliged to examine all accusations presented to it including those made against NATO ORG in particular by pacifist groups from Canada GPE . This compulsory examination was to be carried out in line with accusations submitted. In any case I have with me a statement made by Prosecutor Del Ponte according to which NATO ORG is not at present under any investigation by the Office of the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal ORG for the Former Yugoslavia GPE and there is no formal inquiry process concerning NATO ORG s actions in the Kosovo GPE conflict. All information received during the past six months DATE either from individuals or from groups requesting an investigation of NATO ORG s actions during the Kosovo GPE conflict have been recorded by the Prosecutor. Any other information will of course be analysed by the Prosecutor who will in due course decide whether or not there is cause for action. Until that time Prosecutor Del Ponte has decided not to examine any of the accusations of criminality made against NATO ORG . SPEAKER ID 148 CARDINAL LANGUAGE EL NAME Alavanos I thank the President in Office but I do not agree with him that the purpose of NATO ORG s intervention was to stop a humanitarian disaster because we have a humanitarian disaster in Kosovo GPE today DATE we have the hell of Milosevic PERSON followed by the hell of the KLA EVENT and the NATO ORG forces. The duties that he exercises today DATE have nothing whatsoever to do with the duties that he exercised during his time as Secretary General of NATO ORG . With regard to the judicial structure in Kosovo GPE we have already heard Mr Kouchner on various occasions describe the enormous difficulties he is experiencing in setting up administrative machinery and a judicial structure. As you know the first ORDINAL steps were taken some months ago DATE . We are all aware of the difficulties and particularly the financial difficulties that Mr Kouchner is facing in setting up this administrative machinery and in particular we are aware of the special difficulty involved in recruiting police so as to ensure day to day public safety. This is a responsibility that the European Union ORG takes very seriously Mr Posselt and I would like to mention that at the General Affairs Council ORG held on Monday DATE this issue was repeatedly stressed when we were discussing Kosovo GPE . Statements were made and pressure was brought to bear on the various Member States who have undertaken to make police resources available to honour their commitments. Some Member States are taking refuge in the fact that they have provided military forces and that they cannot send the police forces to which they committed themselves as quickly as they would like. We are certainly very much aware that this factor is seriously compromising Mr Kouchner s work and the normalisation of administrative structures in Kosovo GPE especially as regards judicial structures and police cover. This is having unfortunate and obvious effects on the scope for controlling inter ethnic coordination and we are all conscious that if measures are not taken in the short term we may end up with situations involving the kind of tensions that we witnessed just a few hours ago TIME and that these tensions may be mirrored in other areas of Kosovo GPE . SPEAKER ID 152 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON This is obviously a question which really has to be seen in a NATO ORG context but as the European Union ORG shares NATO ORG s view of these issues it is not difficult for us to associate ourselves with this. I would like to make this clear on behalf of the Council ORG so that there can be no doubt. Mr Marset Campos you will be aware first ORDINAL of all of how difficult it is to select targets during a military operation particularly an air based one and you will also be aware that there is a category of targets that whilst they are not military targets as such are infrastructure targets selected with a view to hindering the smooth running of the military machine. We are of course entering a grey area here and you may say Mr Marset Campos that these are civilian targets such as bridges and road and rail infrastructure whilst others will tell me that they are military targets because they are targets which support military structures in aggressive campaigns such as those carried out by Mr Milosevic PERSON s forces in Kosovo GPE . So we do not see eye to eye on how we view certain targets. P Unfortunately and as everyone recognised during the military action in Kosovo GPE there were civilian sectors and in particular infrastructural sectors directly affecting the general public and even inhabited areas which were directly affected by NATO ORG air attacks. This is generally recognised and this happens in all wars and the Kosovo war was not a clean war nor a model war but a war based on the art of the possible. And above all it was a necessary war and it was not only about what was possible it was necessary to put an end to an absolutely unacceptable form of aggression which was utterly rejected by the entire international community. Mr Marset Campos regardless of how we may see things with hindsight and it is easy to see things with the benefit of hindsight if you take no action yourself I believe that if we look at what happened in Bosnia and Herzegovina GPE and at the impunity that the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina GPE led to and the continuation of that impunity then we might perhaps see the NATO ORG military action in Kosovo GPE in a somewhat less catastrophic light. SPEAKER ID 153 NAME President SPEAKER ID 154 CARDINAL NAME Ursula Schleicher Question No 4 by H 0028 00 ORG P Subject Turkish NORP blockade of Armenia Given GPE that the European Union ORG is actively promoting social economic and political relations with Armenia through the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement ORG signed on 12 October 1999 DATE what steps is the Council ORG taking to persuade the Turkish Government ORG to lift the economic blockade of Armenia GPE ? P Has the time come for the Turkish Government to lift the economic blockade of Armenia GPE ? SPEAKER ID 155 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON . PT Mr President Mrs Schleicher PERSON s question is about a regional conflict and at first ORDINAL sight the question appears to assume that our relations with Turkey GPE and Armenia GPE are merely bilateral. It is obvious that underlying this question is the key issue of Nagorno Karabakh PERSON and also Armenia s conflict with Azerbaijan GPE which have repercussions here of course given the special relationship that Azerbaijan GPE has with Turkey GPE . Nevertheless as regards the relationship that interests us the relationship between the European Union ORG and Armenia GPE the entry into force of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement ORG in July 1999 DATE and the first ORDINAL meeting that we held in October last year DATE show how seriously the European Union ORG takes its relations with Armenia GPE . One CARDINAL of our aims is to extend commercial relations in the area of trade and investment in particular. Another aim is to maintain a bilateral political dialogue with Armenia in view of its major role in that subregion. P P As I said Nagorno Karabakh PERSON is an issue which it is still vital to resolve and one which of course threatens the stability of the southern Caucasus. In our view all efforts to achieve a solution to this conflict must be intensified. This must be our top priority. The European Union ORG has been endeavouring to facilitate this process and we are of course also aware that Turkey GPE must adopt a constructive attitude towards this matter and play a major role in it. In December 1999 DATE as we all know Turkey GPE was accepted as a candidate for membership of the European Union ORG . Political dialogue with Turkey GPE will be stepped up in view of this new situation. The presidency of the European Union ORG which I myself represented visited Ankara GPE immediately after that decision and we stressed to the Turkish NORP authorities the importance of strengthening political dialogue between us. In particular we stressed the need for us to take advantage of Turkey GPE s own importance in the region particularly in relation to central Asia LOC and the Caucasus. We will try to reach common positions on international issues in the context of this relationship with Turkey GPE one which we would like to see become ever closer politically speaking. As I have said this applies in particular in view of the region of which Turkey GPE forms a part and given the importance of its strategic geographical position. We hope that Turkey GPE will adopt a constructive and positive attitude. Above all we hope that in the political dialogue preceding the whole run up to negotiations Turkey GPE will be able to accept the European Union s statements on common foreign and security policy. In this case I feel that Turkey GPE will not be able to avoid our interpretation of the need to find reasonable solutions to the Nagorno Karabakh PERSON situation respecting the legitimate aspects of both Armenia GPE and Azerbaijan GPE s positions. Nevertheless I am a little disappointed that this is viewed from a bilateral angle first ORDINAL and foremost when ultimately there is in fact a major tripartite relationship. We provide partnership funding and there are cooperation agreements in place in order to help Armenia and still the aid cannot come into play because Turkey GPE has imposed an economic blockade and so many things cannot get through to the Armenians NORP at all. We are negotiating with Turkey GPE as to the possibility of its acceding to the Union and so it is in the interests of all of us that every state that wishes to become a Member should cultivate friendly relations with its neighbours. Can you not exert greater influence over Turkey GPE so as to enable there to be peaceful developments in this region and so as to enable Armenians NORP themselves to develop in the way they need to for there to be progress on the cooperation front? SPEAKER ID 157 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PT PERSON Mrs Schleicher you are quite right to say that we should use our relationship with Turkey GPE to ensure that that country can play a constructive role in this situation and particularly that it becomes part of the solution rather than part of the problem. P We feel that precisely because Turkey GPE has embarked on a new type of relationship with the European Union ORG and also because Turkey GPE now has to respond to the European Union ORG s positions on common foreign and security policy issues we will to be frank be testing Turkey GPE s will as regards the European Union ORG s priorities in its foreign relations. Our relationship with Armenia GPE as evinced by the agreement we signed with that country last year DATE is of course one CARDINAL element in these foreign relations. We also feel that if Turkey GPE wishes to move towards sharing the fundamental values of the European Union ORG and the general framework of the European Union s relations regardless of whatever special bilateral conditions may apply to its own relations with any other country it must in general act in accordance with the basic standards demonstrated by the European Union ORG in its foreign relations. We are moreover convinced that this issue will be one of the priorities of the bilateral relations between the European Union ORG and Turkey GPE in the near future. SPEAKER ID 158 CARDINAL NAME President As they deal with the same subject Questions Nos PERSON 5 and 6 will be taken together. SPEAKER ID 159 CARDINAL NAME Efstratios Korakas Question No 5 by H 0031 DATE 00 P Subject Worsening situation in Kosovo GPE In Kosovo GPE the genocide of Serbs NORP and other non Albanian NORP ethnic groups is continuing and worsening to the extent that Mr Bernard Kouchner PERSON himself recently announced that the political situation and the level of security in the area were far from satisfactory. Accusations are also being made of failure to implement UN ORG Directive 1244 CARDINAL since on the one hand its provisions concerning guarantees for all the inhabitants of Kosovo GPE are being disregarded and on the other encouragement is being given to extremist breakaway groups culminating in the appointment of the former KLA ORG leader H. Thaci PERSON as interim prime minister of Kosovo GPE and the designation of the KLA ORG as the Kosovo GPE protection force . P What steps will the Council ORG take in view of the above in order to ensure compliance with UN ORG decisions and in particular resolution 1244 CARDINAL and prevent the secession of the province of Kosovo GPE from Serbia GPE ? SPEAKER ID 160 NAME Pedro Marset PERSON Campos Question No 6 by H 0122 00 DATE P Subject Ethnic cleansing of Serbs NORP in Kosovo Since the end of the bombing of Yugoslavia GPE by NATO ORG and the EU ORG aimed at preventing the ethnic cleansing of Kosovar Albanians NORP by Serbia GPE and since the arrival of KFOR ORG on 12 June 1999 DATE 200 000 Serbs NORP living in Kosovo GPE have been expelled and 768 CARDINAL murdered constituting ethnic cleansing on a larger scale than that carried out by the Serbs NORP themselves. P During the last few days DATE we have seen Serbs NORP murdered by Kosovar Albanian Mafia ORG type groups also with impunity. P What decision will the Council ORG adopt to put an end once and for all to this ethnic cleansing and to guarantee respect for the human rights of the whole population of Kosovo GPE irrespective of race or creed? SPEAKER ID 161 CARDINAL LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON . PT Mr President as I stated in response to a previous question the situation in Kosovo GPE is an issue to which last Monday DATE s General Affairs Council ORG certainly paid a great deal of attention. That Council ORG emphasised its support for the efforts of UNMIK ORG and of Bernard Kouchner PERSON the special representative of the Secretary General and in particular their efforts to create an interim administrative structure in Kosovo GPE under which the guarantee that it will include all sides particularly those which have until now refused to take part in this interim structure will not be an empty one. P P Javier Solana PERSON the High Representative for the common foreign and security policy of the European Union ORG gave this General Affairs Council ORG an assessment of the situation. He is expected to put forward proposals on this matter particularly internal adjustment measures which will allow not only a certain degree of flexibility in inter ethnic relations but will also as I have already stated in response to another question permit the establishment of new police structures and the creation of systems which will enable the Kosovo GPE situation to be prevented from becoming considerably worse in terms of corruption drug trafficking and crime. The forces on the ground have so far been unable to solve these problems. P It is therefore obvious Mr Korakas ORG that the Council of Ministers ORG is still seriously concerned about the current situation in Kosovo GPE particularly about the exodus of the Serbian NORP population and of other ethnic and religious minorities from Kosovo GPE . These minorities are often not mentioned enough when discrimination taking place in Kosovo GPE is discussed. The Council ORG wishes to express its consternation and concern at the degree of inter ethnic violence still being seen. P As I have already said in response to another question the latest outbreak of hostilities in Mitrovica GPE is just another example of the difficulty of overcoming the distrust which has built up over decades DATE . Obviously we are at just one stage of a process which has already passed through various earlier stages and I think that we should always see this stage in the light of history. P The Council of Ministers of the European Union ORG has on several occasions stated its commitment to establishing a democratic NORP and multi ethnic Kosovo GPE in accordance with the terms of United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 ORG . It has in particular declared its commitment to all refugees being able to return safely and without obstacles. P P I would like to make it clear Mr Korakas regardless of the many doubts that we may have concerning Resolution 1244 LAW that it is still the main determinant of our actions in that region. As regards criticisms levelled at the Council ORG I wish to state that the Council ORG condemns all acts of violence persecution and intolerance whoever commits them. P Therefore in response to the current situation the Council ORG has resolutely supported the establishment of the United Nations Mission in Kosovo UNMIK ORG has contributed to its budget and has taken responsibility for the so called fourth ORDINAL UNMIK pillar which is concerned with economic reconstruction and rehabilitation. P P In assessing the progress that UNMIK ORG has made so far we must bear in mind the extremely difficult circumstances in which this organisation is operating. By this I mean the large number of refugees and displaced persons who have had to be rehoused the fact that most of the infrastructure has been destroyed the strength of feeling that still exists in every section of Kosovo GPE s population the fact that the economy has collapsed and the total lack of internal tax income. There is also the fact that administrative structures at local and district level have imploded as have the judicial and police systems. This is all due to the war and to a decade of neglect after Belgrade GPE removed Kosovo GPE s autonomy. This factor is important and it should remain clear in everyone s mind that it was the change in Kosovo GPE s status within the Republic of Yugoslavia GPE that caused the increasing ethnic tensions that gave rise to the current situation. This factor must not be forgotten lest the past actions of those who are historically responsible should also be forgotten. P In these circumstances I think that UNMIK together with the other international bodies and organisations involved must have made some progress in relation to some of the objectives stated in Resolution 1244 LAW although we are still a long way from a situation which is at all satisfactory. P P The Council ORG also supports the decision of the special representative Bernard Kouchner PERSON to establish a provisional joint administrative council which should include all of Kosovo GPE s ethnic groups as I have already mentioned. The European Union ORG has appealed to the Serbs NORP in Kosovo GPE to reconsider their boycott of this structure so that they can contribute to a multi ethnic region and assure themselves a place in the new administrative structures. P On the other hand the European Union ORG is also supporting UNMIK ORG s efforts to construct the Kosovar GPE civil police force with the aim of helping to combat multi ethnic violence and of creating the secure atmosphere necessary to prevent Kosovars PERSON of non Albanian NORP ethnic origin from leaving the province. Although we have already made a substantial contribution we must recognise that until now as I have already said the EU ORG Member States have not been able to detach officers to this police force which has proven to be a very damaging factor for the operation of a public security structure. P As I have said in accordance with the conclusions of the General Affairs Council ORG of 24 January DATE the Member States are doing their utmost to find additional police personnel and the most recent General Affairs Council ORG reiterated this position. Strengthening police forces is also an important task in the context of the growing threat represented by organised crime and the Commission is seeking to include the fight against organised crime in its programme of assistance for Kosovo GPE for 2000 DATE and is asking the Member States to identify what assistance they can provide in this area. P We feel that a large part of the solution to the Kosovo GPE problem and there cannot be very much doubt about this also relates to the problem of stabilising the countries involved. Unless this is done there is no point in thinking that we can solve Kosovo GPE s problems. We therefore need to stabilise the situation in Albania GPE and there are currently proposals for the Commission ORG to evaluate Albania GPE s chances of moving towards a stabilisation and association agreement. We need to stabilise the situation in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and we need to come up with integrated models in the other areas of the former Yugoslavia GPE . Unless we can do all this we will not be able to find separate solutions for Kosovo GPE . It is the overall context in the region and the overall context for implementing the Stability Pact LAW that provide a solution for this situation. SPEAKER ID 162 CARDINAL LANGUAGE EL NAME Korakas Mr President I am sorry but listening to the Council ORG s representative one really has to wonder how far hypocrisy tolerance and complicity can go. It is a fact that as they say in my country in the home of a hanged man one does not mention ropes. Yugoslavia GPE used to be a peaceful country a paragon of stability and peace. It was NATO ORG s interventions and initially those of Germany GPE which led to all that has happened. So it is not the Belgrade Government ORG that is responsible but NATO ORG itself the imperialists and their interventions. What do we have today DATE ? We have a flagrant violation of Security Council Resolution 1244 ORG and this proves that it was a trap. We have 350 000 Serbians Gypsies and other nationalities besides Albanian Kosovars LOC who have been expelled. Nine hundred CARDINAL were murdered 800 CARDINAL abducted and 8 months later DATE we have a continuing and flagrant violation of the Security Council ORG s resolution. For example not only has the KLA EVENT failed to disarm as provided for in the resolution but on the contrary by virtue of Mr Kouchner s assertions in the European Parliament ORG it has acquired modern equipment and has now been designated the Kosovo Protection Force . In conclusion since the Minister mentioned Mr Kouchner I would like to say that with his 25 CARDINAL decrees Kouchner ORG is violating both the sovereignty of Yugoslavia GPE and the Security Council ORG s resolution. He has created a separate currency a judicial body... P The President interrupted the speaker P Let us see things as they are Mr President! SPEAKER ID 163 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PT PERSON I do not think that was a question Mr Korakas ORG those were statements. The first ORDINAL of these which I wish to draw to the House ORG s attention is the idea that Belgrade GPE is not responsible for the situation in Kosovo GPE . I wish to make this clear because it is an important statement and it implies that imperialist action by NATO ORG is responsible for the situation in Kosovo GPE . P This is an odd interpretation although it is perhaps not quite so odd as it is shared by the Serbian NORP authorities but I think that you must understand Mr Korakas that there are other interpretations too. You must also understand that the international community and the EU Council of Ministers ORG have a view of events which is very different to your own. P With regard to Resolution 1244 LAW if it is a trap then I do not understand either why it is that you think that every violation of this trap is considered to be damaging. Resolution 1244 CARDINAL may not be perfect but it was the only resolution that could be agreed upon to bring an end to a particular situation. This resolution has probably been difficult to apply for the simple reason that it presupposes a climate of stability to which neither Mr Milosevic PERSON nor his regime have contributed. P I recognise as we all do that the behaviour of certain Kosovar Albanian NORP forces in Kosovo GPE has been neither desirable nor successful. Mr Kouchner PERSON has been highly critical of this situation and this behaviour. P We should not imagine Mr Korakas that all the blame can be placed on one CARDINAL side. Nor should we imagine that we can forget the past when we are analysing the present. The present particularly in the case of the Balkans LOC and you know this better than I do has its roots in history and in successive historical developments. There are not only good guys in this story. As I see it these situations are quite clear and we should all learn lessons from and accept responsibility for our previous inaction in the face of Mr Milosevic PERSON s behaviour at a time when he could do whatever he wanted in Kosovo GPE with impunity particularly once he had taken away its autonomy. P P SPEAKER ID 164 LANGUAGE ES NAME Marset Campos I thank the Minister for his response but I would also like to point out that statistically there is now more violence in Kosovo GPE than there was before the NATO ORG bombing. It is worrying that the bombing has aggravated the situation and we should recognise that it was a mistake on the part of NATO ORG and the European Union ORG to take such action. I agree with what the Minister very rightly said about the culpability of Belgrade GPE but we should also remember that the secret services of the USA GPE Germany France GPE Italy GPE and the United Kingdom GPE have been supplying arms and money to the KLA ORG a mafia which has contributed to the problems in the area. We are therefore all to blame. P I would like to ask him a supplementary question in a wider context. Do you not think that it would be beneficial to lift the embargo on Serbia GPE in order to normalise the area economically and also to benefit Kosovo GPE as a province of Serbia GPE ? SPEAKER ID 165 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PT PERSON I would like to say Mr Marset Campos that I find it very difficult to make judgments based on suppositions about what might have happened if something else had not happened! Neither you nor I will ever know what might be happening now in Kosovo GPE or what might have happened in Kosovo GPE if NATO ORG had not dropped its bombs. We will never know if the aggressive and ever worsening actions Mr Milosevic PERSON and his government were perpetrating more and more frequently would in fact have had far more dire consequences than those that we are witnessing in Kosovo GPE today DATE . P P With regard to lifting sanctions we think that the European Union ORG s attitude towards Yugoslavia GPE has amounted to a careful assessment of the various situations. We have implemented an Energy for Democracy programme to support democratically governed municipalities in Yugoslavia GPE . We reacted positively at last Monday DATE s General Affairs Council ORG to the request made to us by democratic NORP forces in Serbia GPE that we should lift the air embargo both for international aircraft and for aircraft belonging to Yugoslavia GPE s national airline. These are signs of the European Union s goodwill towards the situation in Serbia GPE . P We must realise that we will not achieve results by making gestures that are not reciprocated. Nor will we achieve results by providing certain kinds of facilities for the Serbian NORP authorities whose actions particularly in the sphere of human rights within Serbia GPE and particularly as regards Serbia GPE s internal political system are still deeply regrettable. I hope that you will agree with me Mr Marset Campos PERSON about the current state of democracy in that country. We shall make appropriate gestures towards Serbia GPE in terms of providing services of lifting sanctions when Serbia GPE s behaviour both on the international stage and in its relations with its neighbouring countries and its behaviour within its own borders is in tune with what we consider to be the fundamental principles governing the international community and the behaviour of decent countries on the world stage. The current situation in Kosovo GPE which is now ethnically cleansed of Serbs NORP and Roma PERSON speaks for itself. SPEAKER ID 167 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON Mr Tannock with regard to the position adopted by the European Union ORG we do not have selective interpretations and analyses of what were military objectives and in particular of the initiatives taken against certain types of infrastructure that were propping up Mr Milosevic PERSON s political system and acting as propaganda for him. I cannot therefore tell you whether we agreed or not on a specific action carried out by NATO ORG but it was part of an overall plan with which we do agree. Some of these actions might have been questionable and some were regarded as unfortunate by NATO ORG itself but others were justified for tactical reasons with the aim of preventing Mr Milosevic PERSON from continuing his propaganda campaign within the former Yugoslavia GPE . In any event I on behalf of the Council ORG do not wish to make a value judgement about any specific military action carried out by NATO ORG . SPEAKER ID 168 CARDINAL LANGUAGE EL NAME Alyssandrakis Mr President in Office of the Council ORG since I know the history of the Balkans LOC I should like to remind you that for many decades DATE the peoples of Yugoslavia GPE lived in peace. Destabilisation began around ten years ago DATE with the break up of Yugoslavia GPE in which the European Union ORG played a decisive part. Yugoslavia GPE s crime was that it was the only Balkan NORP country that did not ask to become a member either of NATO ORG or of the European Union ORG . So whatever remained standing after the air attacks is now being destroyed by the supposedly disarmed KLA ORG under the very nose of KFOR ORG whose role as an occupying force is becoming increasingly apparent. SPEAKER ID 169 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON I respect your understanding and knowledge of the Balkan NORP region Mr Alyssandrakis but I find it difficult quite frankly to understand how respecting the characteristics of the region can in terms of political stability be a solution to the problem. If we look at the democratic stability of the region it could perhaps be said that it was the break up of Yugoslavia GPE that caused the current situation but let us not get involved in interpreting an international development. Nevertheless I would like to say that Yugoslavia GPE was what it was in the sense that the state managed to harmonise some of its people s ethnic differences to a degree. It must be pointed out that it did this at a time when its political framework was far from ideal in terms of being democratically representative. The division of Yugoslavia GPE is probably a historical fact that we shall have to accept regardless of the mistakes that may have been made along the way. We do not feel that withdrawing international forces now would be any kind of solution. Quite the contrary it would be a solution leading to calamity. SPEAKER ID 170 CARDINAL NAME MacCormick Mr President I was a little disappointed with the answer given by the President in Office to my colleague. Secondly ORDINAL what does it propose to do about them? SPEAKER ID 171 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON Mr MacCormick first ORDINAL of all I would like to answer your comments. What I said and what I explained in a previous answer is that there are civilian targets linked with structures which are objects for military action and you know as well as I do that some military actions not only go for military targets but also for civilian targets and structures which are connected with military action. What is a legitimate target is obviously a grey area. As I said we are not making value judgements about specific actions. We are making an overall value judgement about NATO ORG s action and this overall value judgement is positive. We agree with the general view of NATO ORG s action. P With regard to political prisoners in Serbia GPE Mr MacCormick it is obvious that when I say that in Serbia GPE today DATE Mr Milosevic PERSON is not acting in accordance with the rules of a decent society at international level I am referring specifically not just to the way he acts towards his fellow citizens. This is precisely why the European Union ORG is maintaining all its sanctions until Yugoslavia GPE s behaviour on the international stage reflects the values that we have to defend. SPEAKER ID 172 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 173 CARDINAL NAME Rodi Kratsa Tsagaropoulou Question No 7 by H 0035 00 ORG P Subject Drafting of the Charter of Fundamental Rights The general public welcomes the fact that a Charter of Fundamental Rights is to be drawn up. It is also to be hoped that it will meet the challenges of Europe LOC in the 21st century DATE . P What are the Council ORG s views on the substance of the Charter PRODUCT ? What type of rights will the Charter PRODUCT set out economic social and cultural ? Which citizens will it cover those of the European Union ORG or the citizens of all European NORP countries with a view to enlargement? Will it cover immigrants etc.? ? P Will it set out established social rights in the European Union ORG or will it set a broader agenda? What means will the Charter use to ensure that it clearly guarantees equality between the sexes? What are the Council ORG s views on incorporating the Charter into the Treaty on European Union? SPEAKER ID 174 CARDINAL LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON The Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART is one of the most promising aspects of any that we in the European Union ORG are working on at institutional level. As you know the charter stems from a decision of the Cologne European Council ORG . It is a factor that we feel is crucial to the construction of what could be called an ethical pillar for the European Union ORG and of what could be called the European Union ORG s need in aiming to achieve a Union of values to be able to increase its scope not just internally but also in order to give legitimacy to its own image externally based on a common set of values. This is of course extremely important for the Community of Fifteen ORG . Four or five months ago DATE we probably did not think this was so important for the Community of Fifteen ORG . Today we are perhaps already thinking along different lines or at least some of us are. The enlarged Union is also very important specifically with regard to future cultural policies. P The content of the charter is as you know currently under discussion. There have only been two CARDINAL meetings of the preparatory group for the Charter of Fundamental Rights ORG this group is now called the Convention for the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART . There are various problems that must be addressed in this area. First ORDINAL of all we must decide if it is a declaratory text or a binding text. Secondly ORDINAL there is the content of the charter. This applies whether the document is binding or not. In other words we must decide whether it is a collection of all the principles which the Member States advocate and have enshrined in their national constitutions or whether it is a new corpus which could to a certain extent act as a common pattern for the European Union ORG . Then there is a fundamental problem which your question in fact touched upon and which I think is of the utmost importance yet it has still not been resolved. That issue is whether this charter only applies to citizens of the Union or whether it also applies to third ORDINAL country nationals who are resident in the Union. This issue is also under discussion. P P There is also an extremely important issue that of the subordination of legal systems and compatibility between the legal system of the Strasbourg Court ORG and the legal system of the Luxembourg Court ORG . This problem must be resolved when the Charter of Fundamental Rights PRODUCT is drawn up. P You also touched upon the issue of social rights Mrs Kratsa Tsagaropoulou FAC . We will have to find some common ground on this matter. I would like to say as a member of the Portuguese NORP delegation that we regard economic and social rights as a vital part of the European Union ORG s heritage and understand that they must be part of any European Union ORG charter and of any corpus of European Union ORG values. I do not know whether everyone shares this view. P Concerning your last question there is the issue of equality between men and women in the European Union ORG . I am sure that this aspect will certainly be treated with the utmost care in this charter all the more so because during discussions on the Treaty of Amsterdam GPE we ourselves had strong views on this and the provisions of the Treaty of Amsterdam GPE represented a qualitative leap as compared with Maastricht PERSON . P Lastly on the subject of incorporating the charter into the Treaty on European Union I am currently chairing the steering group of the preparatory group for the Intergovernmental Conference ORG . The Portuguese NORP Presidency is keen to ensure that as soon as there is consensus on the charter among the people drafting it it should be incorporated into the Treaty on European Union and that this issue should immediately be referred to the Intergovernmental Conference. As you know the charter does not fall within the competence of the Council ORG but comes under a convention with an elected chairman and representatives of the European Parliament ORG of national parliaments and of the governments of the Member States and of the European Commission ORG . It should be referred to the Intergovernmental Conference as soon as it is ready but we are not in control of this procedure. We are merely monitoring the progress of the charter by means of a vice chairman of the convention who is at the same time the representative of the European Union ORG presidency in this group. SPEAKER ID 175 LANGUAGE EL NAME Kratsa Tsagaropoulou I thank the President in Office for the concerns and certainties he has expressed about the progress of the work. SPEAKER ID 176 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON As I said Mrs Kratsa Tsagaropoulou we are not in control of the procedure for drawing up the Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART . This procedure falls within the competence of the members of the group and the matter will only be submitted to the Council ORG if and when consensus is reached on the terms of this charter. I would nevertheless like to say with regard to the rights of the child that we consider this to be an extremely topical issue particularly for the Council of Europe ORG and in view of the existence of a set of relevant international texts to which we have signed up. This matter should form part of the Charter of Fundamental Rights ORG . This will certainly be the guideline that my government for one will advocate for the Charter of Fundamental Rights ORG . Furthermore we will see if we can do this for a range of other proposals that we have on this issue. I do not know whether these proposals will meet with a favourable reception or not. I presume however that this is not a particularly controversial matter and we think that it would simply involve bringing together the currently agreed corpus of rights which even the most elementary justice would suggest should be included in the charter and be shared by the Union as a whole. SPEAKER ID 182 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 183 CARDINAL NAME Caroline Lucas Question No 8 by H 0042 00 P Subject Granting WORK_OF_ART of export credit guarantees and its implications for the construction of the Ilisu Dam FAC in Turkey GPE The G8 ORG meeting in Cologne GPE called on the OECD ORG to set up a process for the establishment of common standards for the granting of export credits. These can be used to distort competition and support questionable projects. Will the EU ORG take the lead in advancing this process? The need was demonstrated recently by the statement from the British Government ORG that it is minded to grant an export credit licence to a company involved in the construction of the Ilisu Dam FAC in Turkey GPE . The World Bank ORG has decided not to fund the project which will displace 20 000 CARDINAL Kurds NORP potentially limit the fresh water supply to Syria GPE and Iraq GPE and cause ecological damage. What is the Council ORG s view of the involvement of European NORP governments and companies in this project? SPEAKER ID 184 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON . PT To answer your question Mrs Lucas we must consider this issue from two CARDINAL angles. Firstly ORDINAL concerning the system of export credits in general and secondly ORDINAL concerning the project you have mentioned in particular. P P With regard to the general point it should be pointed out that the G8 ORG did not call on the OECD ORG to establish common standards for the granting of export credits as your question suggests. These standards already exist today DATE . The agreement on guidelines for export credit which enjoy official support have been in force within the OECD ORG since 1978 DATE . The objective of these guidelines is precisely to see that officially backed export credits are used properly that is in a transparent and disciplined way. As you know most OECD ORG countries are already party to this agreement and the European Community ORG as such and not the Member States individually is also party to this agreement in accordance with Article 133 formerly Article 113 of the Treaty on European Union LAW . P This agreement has been gradually corrected and improved and the European Union ORG wishes to maintain its pivotal role in this process because it considers this to be of central importance in its international economic relations. P P With regard to the G8 ORG and in accordance with paragraph 32 CARDINAL of the Cologne Summit statement of June 1999 DATE it is stated that we will work with the OECD ORG towards common environmental guidelines for institutions that promote export. We aim to conclude this work by the time the G8 Summit is held in 2001 DATE . The G8 ORG therefore recognise the importance of credits both for exports and for the environment and the importance of the work currently being done within the OECD ORG on this subject. P In 1999 DATE the OECD Ministerial Council ORG meeting in which I took part welcomed the progress made in drawing up an OECD ORG agreement on the exchange of environmental information on large projects involving officially backed export credits. The Council ORG urged that work should continue with the aim of strengthening common platforms pending a report on progress to be made to the next session of the Ministerial Council ORG to be held this year DATE . As you know the Member States of the European Union ORG are playing a central role in this process and in this discussion. P P With regard to the specific point of the Ilisu GPE dam itself discussions are taking place between the Turkish NORP authorities and authorities whose export credit agencies are potential suppliers of export credit insurance for those undertaking the project who took a deliberate decision to make adequate safeguards for the environmental social and cultural implications of this project. Furthermore it was in this context that a representative of the United Kingdom GPE stated in 1999 DATE that he envisaged guaranteeing that export credit insurance would take second ORDINAL place to safeguarding the type of issue that you mentioned in your question Mrs Lucas PERSON . P P The question of an export credit licence does not apply to this project. It is worth pointing out that as funding for the project has not been requested from the World Bank ORG there is no question of the Bank ORG refusing to finance it. It could only refuse of course if such a request had been made. It goes without saying that the involvement of the Member States governments and official export credit agencies in the Ilisu GPE dam project has been in compliance with European Union ORG OECD ORG and G8 ORG political and legal requirements and commitments in the case of the G8 ORG by those countries belonging to that group. SPEAKER ID 187 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 188 CARDINAL NAME Patricia McKenna Question PERSON No 9 by H 0044 00 DATE P Subject Environmental ORG problems caused by the Drogheda Port Company ORG development project and the role of the Court of Auditors ORG A major conflict between environmental conservation and structural development interests has arisen in the area of the Boyne Estuary Ireland following a development project of the Drogheda Port Company ORG . The affected area is designated a Special Protection Area SPA under the Wild Birds Directive ORG and is under consideration for a Special Area of Conservation under the Habitats Directive as it is an area of international importance. Many local and European NORP associations have strongly criticised the project. Similar cases occur in other regions of the Union where EU ORG development funding conflicts with environmental unsustainability of the beneficiary measures. Is not the Council of the opinion ORG that the Court of Auditors ORG should be given more resources in order to investigate or review similar development measures where environmental conflicts arise? What kind of measures does the Council ORG plan to take in order to strengthen the review and evaluation powers of the European NORP institutions in similar cases? SPEAKER ID 189 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON . PT In response to your question Mrs McKenna PERSON I would first ORDINAL of all like to highlight the fact that the role of the Court of Auditors ORG was laid down in the Treaty establishing the European Community ORG . In accordance with Article 246 of the Treaty LAW the auditing of accounts is carried out by the Court of Auditors ORG which to this end studies the accounts of all revenue and expenditure of the Community ORG as well as the regularity and the legality of the underlying transactions. The Court ORG also guarantees proper financial management. This is indeed also stipulated in Article 248 LAW . P The Court of Auditors ORG therefore already has all the instruments necessary to carry out its role. With regard to your suggestion for increasing the Court ORG s resources the Council ORG considers that all of the Union s institutions have under the Community ORG budget the necessary financial means for them to be able to properly carry out their respective remits. In some cases it would probably be desirable for their financial resources to be increased but there are budgetary restraints of which I am sure you are aware. I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that the Budget of the European Union ORG is approved by common agreement between the Council ORG and this Parliament ORG . The Council ORG therefore has no means of changing the role conferred on the Court of Auditors ORG by the Treaty ORG . SPEAKER ID 190 CARDINAL NAME McKenna PERSON If extra resources were given to the Court of Auditors ORG it would be money well spent because it would ensure that EU ORG funding was not going to something that conflicted with environmental concerns. For years DATE the Council ORG has been blocking the strategic development impact assessment of plans and programmes. I would ask you now that you are President of the Council ORG will you push forward with this extremely important proposal. Secondly ORDINAL as there is no mention of Structural Funds ORG in the current draft could you ensure that this would be put back in? P I would like to know what you could do about this as President in Office of the Council ORG at the moment because it is the Council ORG that has been blocking this for a long time. It is extremely important. If the Court of Auditors ORG were able to assess regularly the potential conflicts between environmental concerns and structural development it would be very important because the Court of Auditors ORG could do an extremely good job. Their reports are extremely detailed and very important. This is the way to ensure that such conflicts are avoided in the future. SPEAKER ID 191 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PT PERSON Mrs McKenna PERSON a large part of the problem you have raised relates to issues which are the responsibility of the Commission. It is therefore the Commission that must ensure that certain development projects comply with relevant environmental provisions. The Commission will have to provide specific answers to these questions. I do not think that I can give a more complete answer on the specific case that you quoted. SPEAKER ID 192 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 193 CARDINAL NAME Jonas Sj PERSON stedt Question No 10 by H 0053 00 DATE P Subject Statute for Members of the European Parliament The Council ORG and Parliament ORG are going to try to reach agreement on a Statute for the Members of the European Parliament ORG . One CARDINAL of the matters to be settled is whether Members are to receive equal pay and where they are to pay tax. According to media reports the Portuguese NORP Presidency considers that all Members should pay the same tax to the EU ORG . This is in conflict with the view taken by some Member States who wish to have the right to tax their Members in their home countries. Will the Portuguese NORP Presidency clarify its position on this matter? SPEAKER ID 194 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON . PT The Portuguese NORP Presidency is particularly interested in this issue as I suppose that this is the first ORDINAL time a presidency has made resolving the problem of a Statute for Members of the European Parliament ORG a priority in its programme. P The Portuguese NORP Presidency made reaching an agreement on this statute one of its priorities as furthermore did the President of the European Parliament ORG when she stated this at the Helsinki European Council ORG . We are therefore in perfect and total agreement in our concern to achieve a positive outcome on this matter. P We are therefore taking advantage of this political will in an attempt to define the outlines of a compromise and we have already begun work on this matter. It is worth pointing out once more that this compromise will require the unanimous support of the Council ORG in accordance with Article 190 LAW and the assent of this Parliament ORG to which it falls to approve this statute. P The Presidency has engaged in intensive discussions with a range of Members of this Parliament ORG and with the group to which Parliament ORG entrusted the task of negotiating with the Council ORG . I myself had an opportunity to meet this group for the first ORDINAL time in parallel with the January DATE part session and I am trying to arrange to do so again soon in order to continue these discussions. These discussions have also recommenced more intensively in the relevant bodies of the Council ORG and I think that I can say in a spirit of openness and greater flexibility and because we all recognise the importance that this has particularly for the general public that drawing up this statute is a vital factor in ensuring both the dignity of the functions of Members of the European Parliament ORG and the necessary transparency and good management of public funds. P With regard more specifically to your question I would like to highlight the fact that it only makes sense to have a new statute if it represents progress in comparison with the current situation and if it ensures that holders of identical posts are as far as possible treated in the same way. This has from the outset been the position of the Portuguese NORP Presidency. P Nevertheless our role as mediator means that we must take account of all current attitudes in the Council ORG and I am sure you are aware Mr Sj stedt that the tax issue poses problems for certain delegations. As this is the case whatever solution is found I think that it will have to respect both democratic NORP law and be acceptable to all Member States regardless of their national positions on the matter. What I can promise with regard to this issue is that the presidency has the utmost commitment to working for as long as it is involved with this matter in an atmosphere of total transparency and openness towards Members of the European Parliament ORG . We will also make the utmost effort with members of the Council ORG particularly with those who had most difficulty in accepting the proposal suggested last year DATE so as to reach a reasonable compromise solution and one which would at the same time guarantee the dignity appropriate for a statute for the members of this House ORG . SPEAKER ID 195 LANGUAGE SV NAME Sj stedt Mr President I would thank the Council of Ministers ORG for its answer. I want to ask two CARDINAL follow up questions connected with the taxation of ourselves as parliamentarians. My basic view is that one CARDINAL ought to pay tax in the country in which one lives in which one CARDINAL s family lives and in which one benefits from public services. I intended to ask the presidency if there really is an argument for saying that we should not pay tax in our own countries just as other people do. Is there any argument for our being given a special privilege just because we are parliamentarians? That is my first ORDINAL question. P My second ORDINAL question is about whether the Portuguese NORP Presidency can accept a solution which involves the tax issue s being solved in different ways for Members of different nationalities or whether you want a solution which is identical for members of all nationalities. SPEAKER ID 196 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON PT Without wishing to show any lack of respect towards this House ORG and particularly because of the respect that your questions deserve I would rather not answer the questions you have raised immediately. We are in the midst of rather sensitive negotiations. This sensitivity is reflected in the way in which the Presidency of the Council of the European Union ORG expresses itself in a specific context in relation to particular situations. This has an impact of course because it is read by other members of the Council ORG . P At this stage in the discussion please forgive me if I cannot give a direct answer to the specific questions that have been put to me. I would ask that we be judged on our results when we endeavour to reach a more concrete solution in the near future. I will be happy to come back to Parliament ORG to respond to and clarify the problems which may conceivably occur if a result is not reached or to congratulate all of you if this result is achieved. SPEAKER ID 197 CARDINAL NAME Purvis I would like to ask the President in Office of the Council ORG after his few hours working in this Chamber with these Members of the European Parliament ORG whether he has come to any assessment of what they are worth in terms of pay? SPEAKER ID 198 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON Mr Purvis as this discussion of salaries in the European Parliament ORG does not relate exclusively to your country and even affects my country I have a precise idea of what the salaries of the Members of the European Parliament ORG are worth. I am therefore perfectly aware of this problem. SPEAKER ID 199 LANGUAGE SV NAME Andersson Mr President I want to thank you for your answer. I want to ask a follow up question which bears some resemblance to the one CARDINAL Mr Sj stedt asked. We both come from Sweden GPE . In our country we pay our tax in the form of local taxes because the services concerned are local. We have extensive services too. We have problems stemming from the lack of confidence in politicians and not least in European NORP politicians here in Parliament ORG . P How do you think that public confidence in ourselves as politicians would be affected if a situation were to arise in which we obtained the right to use services where we live education health care etc but at the same time did not pay any tax and did not contribute? How do you think a system like that would affect people s confidence in ourselves as politicians? SPEAKER ID 200 CARDINAL NAME President Mr President in Office of the Council ORG I do not know whether you are obliged to answer this question since it is really a philosophical question. However if you wish to enter into the realms of philosophy go ahead! SPEAKER ID 201 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seixas da Costa PERSON . Mr President I have no desire to enter into the realms of philosophy. These are fundamental issues which concern the very shape of the Statute for Members and of its role in the context of political society. I do not want to enter into this type of discussion because I think that it might to use a French NORP expression pr juger the Portuguese NORP Presidency s views in the course of the negotiations in which it is involved on the Statute for Members. I would ask you to allow me to refrain from commenting on this matter. SPEAKER ID 202 CARDINAL NAME President Since the time allotted to Questions to the Council ORG has elapsed Questions Nos 11 CARDINAL to 35 will be replied to in writing. P That concludes Questions PERSON to the Council ORG . P The sitting was suspended at 7.05 p.m. TIME and resumed at 9.00 p.m. QUANTITY CHAPTER ID 12 Address LAW by Mr Vaclav Havel PERSON President of the Czech Republic GPE SPEAKER ID 203 CARDINAL NAME President Mr President in office ladies and gentlemen I have great honour in extending a warm welcome on behalf of the House ORG to the President of the Czech Republic Mr GPE Vaclav Havel PERSON . P P I should also like to welcome Mrs Havel who is sitting in the gallery. You are most welcome. P Applause P This is not your first ORDINAL visit to our Parliament ORG Mr President. You addressed plenary in Strasbourg GPE nearly six years ago DATE in March 1994 DATE and many of us who were already European NORP Members of Parliament ORG at that time still have a vivid recollection of your speech. P In fact shortly after the Maastricht Treaty LAW was ratified you spoke in favour of strengthening European NORP values creating a European NORP ethical dimension and opening the Union to the countries of central and eastern Europe LOC . In other words for many citizens and not just in your country you personify the European NORP values to which we constantly voice our attachment. P There have been extremely dynamic developments in relations between the Union and the Czech Republic GPE following two CARDINAL European NORP elections and a major new reform of the European NORP Treaties. An association agreement has been signed and a joint parliamentary committee has been set up by the European Parliament ORG and the Czech NORP Parliament ORG . Your country filed an official application to join the Union in 1996 ORG and accession negotiations were finally officially opened in 1998 DATE . P The process of European NORP integration and enlargement has speeded up impressively since the fall of DATE the iron curtain. The end of this artificial separation of Europe LOC marked the start of a new era. We now face an historical challenge with multiple prospects for all the citizens of Europe LOC . P Mr President you are a symbol of these changes. You founded and signed Charter 77 CARDINAL the human rights movement which represented and called for fundamental values during a dark period in the history of your people. A Communist NORP regime sentenced you to five years DATE in prison for defending human freedom and dignity. But you never lost hope and history proved you right. Ten years ago DATE the velvet revolution proclaimed Havel na HRAD. P For ten years DATE you represented democratic Czechoslovakia GPE and later the Czech Republic GPE as its president. Reconciliation with your neighbours was and still is a basic objective which you have defended with vigour and perseverance. You are a first ORDINAL class European NORP . P Today DATE the Czech Republic GPE is preparing to join our Union. I am sure that you will agree Mr President and experience has shown us that the process of enlargement of the Union is not without its pitfalls for both parties and the Czech Republic GPE will need to make a great deal of effort in order to meet the accession criteria. P The European Union ORG for its part will need to adapt its institutions and policies in order to prepare for enlargement. It has already taken a big step forward with Agenda 2000. The next step i.e. institutional reform will be taken following the inauguration of the new Intergovernmental Conference in which the European Parliament ORG will be fully involved. P Our responsibility as members of the European Parliament ORG is to ensure that the process of enlargement takes place in an climate of optimum openness and transparency so that when the time comes the citizens of the European Union ORG and the citizens of the Czech Republic GPE will approve the accession of the Czech Republic GPE to the European Union ORG through their elected representatives. P Mr President it gives me great pleasure to give you the floor. P Applause SPEAKER ID 204 CARDINAL NAME Vaclav Havel PERSON Madam President members of the European Parliament ORG ladies and gentlemen the question of whether deep down a European NORP has a sense of European NORP identity alongside a sense or awareness of national identity crops up time and time again nowadays. In other words do Europeans NORP really feel they are Europeans NORP or is it more of an abstract idea a theoretical concept designed to repackage a geographical factor as a state of mind? This question also crops up during the debate on the degree of sovereignty which the nation states can and should transfer to the institutions of the European Union ORG . Some insist that if a clearly felt national identity is eclipsed too quickly by a European NORP identity which few feel or which is even perceived as fanciful then things are sure to take a turn for the worse. P So what exactly do we mean by Europeanism PERSON ? P If I look deep into my heart and try to identify the point at which I start to feel European NORP and what unites me to Europe LOC the first thing I feel is mild surprise at the fact that it is only now under the pressure of topical political issues and duties that I even ask myself the question. Why did I not put this question to myself a long time ago when I started to make my way in the world and reflect on the world and my place in it? Did I consider my attachment to Europe LOC as a purely extrinsic factor of little significance a factor which did not need to concern let alone torment me? Or on the contrary did I consider my Europeanism as so self evident that it did not warrant interrogation examination or further thought? P The second ORDINAL proposition is the more likely everything with which I have always identified myself was so naturally European NORP that it never occurred to me to consider it as such. I simply did not see any point in qualifying it or generally in associating my way of thinking with a specific continent. Furthermore I have the feeling that as a young man I might well have felt slightly silly saying or writing that I am a European NORP that my perceptions and way of thinking are European NORP or even explicitly claiming that I was from Europe LOC . It would have seemed profoundly pathetic and presumptuous a more arrogant version of the national patriotism which has always embarrassed me. P In other words I was so obviously and naturally European NORP that I did not even think about it. And I am sure that applies to the majority of Europeans NORP . They are profoundly European NORP but they are not even aware of it they do not hang that label round their necks which is why opinion polls show that they are somewhat surprised at having to shout their Europeanism from the rooftops. P There does not appear to be a great tradition of considered Europeanism in Europe LOC . P That is not necessarily a good thing and I welcome with satisfaction the fact that our Europeanism is starting to emerge clearly today DATE from the vast melting pot of concepts which speak for themselves . Questioning considering and trying to define it helps us enormously in understanding ourselves. It is becoming a determining factor in the multicultural and multifaceted world in which we live in which the capacity to perceive one CARDINAL s own identity is a prerequisite to peaceful coexistence with other identities. Moreover if Europe LOC has thought so little about its own identity in the past that is no doubt because it considered itself wrongly to be the entire world or at least it considered itself to be better than the rest of the world because it did not feel the need to define itself in relation to others. Which of course had unfortunate consequences as far as its actual conduct was concerned. P Thinking about Europeanism means asking what set of values ideals or principles puts you in mind of the notion of Europe LOC even what is typical of Europe LOC . More than that it also means starting from the very essence of the thing examining the whole concept critically. And hence quickly realising that numerous European NORP traditions values or principles are typically highly ambiguous and may lead to ruin if exaggerated exploited or abused. P If Europe LOC has entered an era of self examination that means that it wishes to define itself in relation to others and also that it wants to identify what is good about itself what has proven its worth and what should be retained for the future. P When I first had the honour of addressing this House ORG six years ago DATE I mentioned the need to emphasise the spiritual dimension and the importance of the values of European NORP integration and I confided my fear that the spiritual historic political and civilising aspects of Europe LOC might be hijacked by questions of a technical economic financial or administrative nature which risked upsetting the public. At the time my words sounded somewhat provocative and I expected to be booed out of the House ORG . But no such thing happened and it is satisfying to note that these same words now no longer sound provocative at all.
