SPEAKER ID 233 LANGUAGE EL NAME Korakas Mr President the agreement being promoted will be the first ORDINAL application of the Stability Pact LAW in south eastern Europe LOC P Its terms which the Swoboda PERSON report accepts are certainly not directed towards peace but towards greater political and economic dominance of the country and towards controlling its natural wealth overexploiting its workforce and continuing to use that country as a springboard against the countries and peoples in the area who are resisting the new order. All this in exchange for the promise of future accession to the European Union ORG . The report accepts these attitudes along with the more general policy of the European Union ORG on south eastern Europe LOC . P It is characteristic that the report congratulates FYROM PRODUCT on the constructive stance it maintained during the NATO ORG attack eulogises its pacifist role because it allowed its territory to be used as a base for NATO ORG forces but of course remains silent about the indignation of its people which was manifested by mass demonstrations during the NATO ORG bombardments. P Finally because we consider that both the stability pact and the stabilisation and association process the European Union ORG is implementing in countries in that area will create new problems there new tribulations for their peoples and will reinforce the dominant role of the American NORP and European NORP imperialists we will be voting against the report in an expression of our solidarity with the people of FYROM. SPEAKER ID 234 LANGUAGE EL NAME Zacharakis Mr President Commissioner one of the most basic aims of the European Union s stability and association agreement with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is to establish stability and peace in the area and this of course presupposes developing and maintaining good neighbourly relations between the countries involved. P I shall not bother you with details of the problem concerning the name FYROM PRODUCT which as you must know is the subject of a difference of opinion with Greece GPE and of negotiations between the two CARDINAL countries lasting over four years DATE under the aegis of the Secretary General of the UN ORG in the context of related Security Council ORG resolutions but also the conventional obligation of the respective parties pursuant to Article 5 of the so LAW termed Intermediate Agreement ORG of 1995 DATE . P I do however think it appropriate to say that at the forthcoming negotiations and with the conclusion of the association agreement the European NORP side must point out to the Skopje ORG government the need for it to show appropriate constructive political will so that it may contribute positively to a successful outcome of the talks in New York GPE . I should like to hope that such an appeal from Europe LOC with parallel emphasis on the difficulties that any further indecision would create for completing and implementing the association agreement would be duly heeded and appraised accordingly by the Skopje ORG government so that it can respond appropriately on the one hand to Greece s demonstrably conciliatory attitude concerning the specific issue and on the other hand to the more general practical declared intention and disposition of all the partners in the European Union ORG including Greece to facilitate and support FYROM s progress towards a United Europe LOC . P Mr President this is because I do not think that the harmonious day to day relations contacts and communication between FYROM and Greece that have actually been achieved at both bipartite and multipartite level and this mainly thanks to the practical arrangements of the intermediate agreement I repeat I do not think these sufficiently cover the conditions and criteria of good neighbourliness necessary inter alia for negotiating and concluding an association agreement. On the contrary I think that this demand can only be considered satisfied by a de jure full normalisation of FYROM s PRODUCT relations with all its neighbours. That combined with the essential improvement of certain aspects of the internal situation in that country in the area of minorities and democratic institutions would round off the image of political maturity which FYROM has in fact presented in other respects and which has made our European NORP family welcome closer relations with it. SPEAKER ID 235 CARDINAL LANGUAGE EL NAME Souladakis Mr President the agreement we are debating today DATE as analysed by Mr Swoboda PERSON which I hope we will adopt tomorrow DATE constitutes the second ORDINAL politically positive step after the stability pact for the area. P There is another small step which is related to the recent partial lifting of the embargo decided by our 15 CARDINAL governments for Yugoslavia GPE . For about 10 years DATE the situation in the area has been fluid. Both as an historical period and in particular as a political period 10 years DATE is a very long time. Under those conditions then there has been a real failure. In that sense the agreement we will be voting on tomorrow DATE which contributes towards stability in the area is de facto a move in the right direction. In essence FYROM PRODUCT is a miniature version of the former Yugoslavia GPE regardless of where one CARDINAL or another minority holds supremacy. From that standpoint the fact that so far it has resisted any influences from its wider environment is a very positive element and under no circumstances should any of us any State ORG any policy or any view impel that small republic towards external disruptive movements in an effort to solve other problems granted let it be noted that it has institutions which it can build upon still further and so become a real democracy. P In that area there have been various policies from time to time and what the European Union ORG should guard against is the risk that for ultimately superficial reasons it may help to create banana republics elsewhere. We must be sure that in seeking allies in the area we must not always choose anyone who offers. We must choose those which are moderate which have breadth of vision and which have a perception of peace and stability in the area. P I hope and wish and am indeed certain that the European Union ORG with maturity and with the measures it has begun to adopt will little by little construct in the wider area the necessary environment which it needs itself. Let us not deceive ourselves a Europe LOC one CARDINAL part of which is being held back because of frictions misinterpretations and conflicts and because of nationalistic clashes will never be a Europe LOC that has brought its own house to the level it wants. P In any event speaking now as a Greek NORP I want to tell some of the speakers I listened to earlier that much of what was said is fixated on other times and places. They have quite failed to grasp the new conditions created in the area the new and positive conditions which have been created in very many cases on Greece s initiative. You should know that the country which cooperates most with FYROM and has the best relations with it in the entire area is Greece GPE and this has contributed greatly to the stability of the area. I say this just so that we know where we stand. SPEAKER ID 236 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DE NAME Posselt Mr President I found what Mr Souladakis PERSON said much more sensible than the statements by other colleagues from his Member State. So I must say quite plainly that anyone who tries to tie the agreement with Macedonia GPE to resolving the issue of the country s name as he does will not only find Macedonia itself against him but all the other EU ORG Member States too. Let me also say quite openly that he is thereby doing huge damage to his own country s interests. It is in our interest to see stability and peace in the Balkans LOC and there is a chance of that although the Stability Pact LAW is in danger of becoming a stillborn entity. I hope that is not the case but the risk is there. That is precisely why it is so urgent for the EU ORG to take a bilateral approach to the individual states and for us to open up definite prospects of EU ORG membership for Macedonia GPE . So I welcome Mr Swoboda s PERSON excellent report especially paragraph 12 CARDINAL which quite clearly maps out a European NORP an EU ORG prospect for Macedonia GPE . Without indulging in any illusions I believe that is important it has to happen. P We know it cannot happen overnight but a definite statement to the effect that Macedonia GPE is quite clearly a European NORP country and therefore has the right to be a member of the European Union ORG is a most important confidence building measure. In my view this is a unique opportunity to strengthen a democracy that has not only established a unique multi ethnic government in this region but is also strengthening the autonomy of the local authorities reforming the judicial and economic systems and doing so under the most difficult conditions in the aftermath of nationalism Communism and war. P A few years ago DATE I had the privilege of inviting the current President and Prime Minister here as private individuals. At the time they were still finding it very difficult to build on their various contacts here. I am very happy to see they have kept the promise they made at the time to build up a profoundly European NORP democracy. We must thank them for playing this important role in moving towards peace stability and democracy at a very critical time last year DATE as I said and at a strategically crucial point. So we are not just the donors here we were also the recipients and we owe it to the Macedonians NORP to thank them for fulfilling a crucial European NORP mission at that time. That is why it is important to negotiate and ratify the agreement promptly rapidly to upgrade the EU ORG representation to official delegation status for our Commissioner to visit Macedonia GPE very soon as I hear he will and for us to open up a definite prospect of EU ORG membership for this country as the Swoboda PERSON report does. SPEAKER ID 237 CARDINAL NAME Patten . This has been a very interesting general debate about the Balkans LOC as a whole. It was none the worse for that but perhaps I will be forgiven for concentrating very largely on the report because there are some extremely important issues that I want to touch on. P I am delighted to be able to be able to set out the Commission ORG s position on the report. It is very helpful. It is an excellent contribution by Mr Swoboda PERSON and his colleagues. We are very grateful for his leadership on this issue and for that of some of his colleagues a number of whom are in the House ORG this evening TIME Mrs Pack Mr Lagendijk PERSON and others. P I am very pleased that at our overall relations with FYROM are in such a good state. Perhaps Mr Dupuis will forgive me for using that expression both he and his interpreter in the spirit of entente cordiale. That has been helped by our excellent European Union ORG representative in the country. He has been a great friend to Parliament ORG and a great servant of the Commission. P The imminent commencement of negotiations on a stabilisation and association agreement is the most powerful example of our good relations. So to is the cooperation of FYROM PRODUCT in the rebuilding of Kosovo GPE . I am grateful to the authorities in Macedonia GPE for their assistance in recent weeks DATE in helping to cope with the considerable difficulties with the power supply in Kosovo GPE . Like honourable Members I recognise the stabilising role that this country has played during the Balkan NORP tragedy in particular when it comes to integrating the Albanian NORP minority into the political and social life of the country. I saw the newly elected President Georgievski PERSON a few weeks ago DATE and I was extremely impressed as others have been by his commitment to multi ethnicity and pluralism. P Let me set out where matters now stand on these negotiations to which as Mr Lagendijk said other countries in the region are looking with very considerable interest. P The Council ORG adopted on 24 January this year DATE its negotiating directives for a stabilisation and association agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic GPE of Macedonia. This represents the most important step forward in the stabilisation and association process of the western Balkans LOC region initiated by the Commission in May 1999 DATE . P Let me make clear the main elements of those draft directives. They cover the inclusion in the agreement of arrangements establishing a political dialogue with FYROM. They cover provisions for enhanced regional cooperation including the prospect of establishing free trade areas between the countries of the region though I must make it clear that there is no question of any attempt to recreate the state of Yugoslavia GPE . They cover the prospect of the establishment of a free trade area between the European Union ORG and them within ten years DATE of the entry into force of the agreement. They cover provisions on the movement of workers freedom of establishment supply of services current payments and movement of capital. They cover a commitment by FYROM to approximate its legislation to that of the European Community ORG notably in key areas of the internal market and they cover provisions on cooperation with FYROM in a wide range of fields including justice and home affairs. P We are now making in the Commission the necessary preparations so that negotiations can start in March DATE . I am due to visit FYROM PRODUCT in the second week in March DATE . I hope to be able to set the process in motion then although the formal negotiations will start very shortly thereafter. At the time of that visit I will also as recommended by honourable Members and others be upgrading our representation in FYROM. P The target date for concluding the negotiations is December this year DATE but this will depend to a very large extent on the goodwill and determination of the negotiators. The agreement could enter into force in three to four years DATE from now given the time needed for ratification in Member States GPE parliaments. P I should like to comment very briefly on a number of other points in the draft resolution. We accept that the agreement should to a certain extent serve as an example for other such agreements although obviously we will also want to take account of the fact that we are dealing with different countries each of which has its own identity and its own concerns. I share the wide spread concern that we should treat each country on its merits and not shackle everyone to the pace of the slowest in the development of relations with the Union. That has never been the intention. The very fact that negotiations are beginning first ORDINAL with FYROM before all the others is evidence that we can and do differentiate. P On the provision of regional aid referred to in the report we agree that our technical and financial assistance should go in part to projects having a cross border or regional dimension. We agree that there should be an evolutionary clause on the prospect of EU ORG membership contained in the stabilisation and association agreement. It will reflect the European Union ORG s position on its relations with the countries of the western Balkans LOC as set out in the Cologne European Council ORG conclusions. P We strongly agree on the need to decentralise our assistance programmes to the maximum possible extent. As for the arrangements covering European Union ORG assistance to the western Balkans NORP Members will be aware that we are drawing up a new regulation to simplify and streamline their management and to put everything under one regulation. I am aware that there is concern in FYROM and elsewhere at the end of the PHARE ORG programme in these countries and especially at the loss of association with the PHARE ORG name. I note with considerable concern what Members say on this score. I will take another look at the issue although I should point out that having two CARDINAL PHARE ORG programmes up and running risks real confusion. I want to stress however that whatever the programme is called our commitment to the integration of FYROM and its neighbours into the European NORP family is stronger than ever. P In general I trust that Members of this House ORG will share my pleasure that Macedonia GPE has reached this stage relatively rapidly. I hope that the other countries of the region will redouble their efforts to make similar progress. I look forward to many similar debates to this over the next few years DATE marking I hope the success of what we are trying to do in the Balkans LOC which for me remains the single most important litmus test of what Europe LOC is able to do on its own doorstep. P SPEAKER ID 238 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you very much Commissioner Patten PERSON . P The debate is closed. P The vote will take place tomorrow DATE at 12.00 p.m. MONEY CHAPTER ID 15 Agreement on comitology SPEAKER ID 239 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is the report A5 0021 2000 PRODUCT by Mrs Frassoni on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs ORG on the agreement between the European Parliament ORG and the Commission on the implementation of the new Council ORG decision of 28 June 1999 DATE on comitology 1999 DATE 468 EC ORG . SPEAKER ID 240 LANGUAGE CARDINAL IT NAME Frassoni . IT Mr President the approval of this agreement with the Commission on procedures for implementing the Council ORG decision on comitology marks the end of a saga which has kept Parliament ORG busy for two years DATE along with a few enthusiasts scattered among the various institutions of the Union whom many people do not hesitate to call masochists. P Until 1993 DATE the way the Commission exercised its executive powers and in particular the mysterious and even suspect committee arrangements was creating conflict and mistrust between the institutions and threatening to have serious consequences on the legislative procedure. That is why in accordance with Declaration No 31 annexed to the Treaty of Amsterdam the Union institutions have undertaken a complex task of negotiation and consultation resulting in the new Council ORG decision which revises the old system quite substantially although we are not entirely satisfied with it. In particular the decision outlines a form of parliamentary control whereby Parliament ORG can sound the alarm if an implementing measure deriving from an act adopted under the codecision procedure oversteps the implementing powers delegated to the Commission. P During the protracted interinstitutional negotiations which saw Parliament ORG actively involved thanks to the work of the rapporteur Adelaide Aglietta FAC it was understood that the European Parliament and Commission ORG would conclude an interinstitutional agreement on the procedures for implementing certain aspects of the new decision. On the one hand certain points which the Council ORG did not intend to incorporate into the decision were to be made explicit and on the other the system for providing information about implementing measures and monitoring them was to be organised more precisely. P During the trialogue held on 6 October 1999 DATE in Strasbourg GPE the Presidents of the European Parliament ORG and the Commission approved the idea of concluding this agreement soon. We believe we have respected that commitment and indeed this was made relatively easy by the climate of trust and mutual respect evident throughout the negotiations with the Commission. P Essentially the agreement deals with two CARDINAL points one is the right of the European Parliament ORG to be informed which is the sine qua non for the genuine exercise of its right to intervene pursuant to Article 8 LAW of the decision. Hitherto such information had been supplied on paper and unsystematically and was of no use to our services and indeed this was often the fault of Parliament ORG itself. From now on the information will be provided by means of an electronic system called CIRCA ORG to which the European Parliament ORG will have access. This represents a real innovation not only for us but also I am sure for the Commission. P The other point is that Article 8 of the Council LAW decision does not specify either the method by which the European Parliament ORG is to sound the alarm or the time limit within which it must exercise its restricted power of control. Paragraphs 6 CARDINAL and 7 CARDINAL of the agreement confirm that as a general rule the European Parliament ORG will adopt its resolution stating its reasons at a plenary sitting and has one month DATE to exercise its right of intervention before the Commission adopts the draft implementing measure. But we all realise that it is not always possible to wait a month DATE before implementing a measure. Therefore the agreement contains explicit provisions on urgent procedure including possible action by the committee responsible. P I want to end by stressing that we cannot assess whether this is a good agreement or not we must wait and see how it works in practice. The European Parliament ORG needs to acquire the resources which it currently lacks to ensure efficient monitoring of implementing measures and the Commission must accept that some of its practices need reorganising to provide proper information to Parliament ORG and ensure that control can be effective. P Finally it needs to be borne in mind that whatever happens the real solution to the problems of comitology for the European Parliament ORG is still to change the procedure for implementing legislation laid down in the Treaties and gradually to dismantle the committees whose existence represents an anomaly GPE that severely restricts the Commission ORG s executive power and may prejudice the European NORP Parliament ORG s legislative powers. SPEAKER ID 241 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DE NAME Schleicher Mr President comitology is a concept most people do not know how to handle and hardly anyone knows what it means. It makes them think of secret societies and conspiracies which is the way things used to be. In fact it implies nothing other than fixing the procedures for the exercise of the implementing powers conferred on the Commission. The procedures for exercising these implementing powers take the form of a limited number of committee procedures. P Up until the Amsterdam Treaty LAW there were about 20 variations of these committee procedures which created neither clarity in the implementation of legislation nor transparency for the citizens. On the contrary for a long time even the European Parliament ORG was not informed. For the European Parliament ORG the first ORDINAL step in the struggle for more transparency in this jungle of committees was to be informed at least of all that the European Commission ORG intended to regulate in the context of these various committees. P Agreement was reached in 1988 DATE in the form of an exchange of letters between Lord Plumb and Mr Delors. A further step towards transparency and the involvement of the European Parliament ORG came with what is known as the modus vivendi of 20 September 1994 DATE which granted Parliament ORG the right not only to be informed but also to intervene in certain cases. It also gave it the possibility of scrutiny. With the Amsterdam Treaty ORG the situation improved decidedly when the number of committee procedures was drastically reduced as the European Parliament ORG had long wanted to three procedures the administrative procedure the regulatory procedure and the advisory procedure. P Now following the Amsterdam Treaty LAW the rights of information and control granted to the European Parliament ORG in the past need to be enshrined anew in an interinstitutional agreement. Mrs Frassoni our rapporteur has done very careful work and identified the questions that have to be clarified in the context of that interinstitutional agreement and the administrative procedures that may have to be changed within Parliament ORG . A key problem is the time factor. When the European Parliament ORG is informed it generally has to adopt a position within the very short timeframe of four weeks DATE should it so wish. In matters relating to the health and safety of the people of the European Union the European Commission ORG as guardian of the Treaties and the only institution with the right of initiative must be in a position to react very rapidly if necessary within a few hours or days TIME . Nevertheless the European Parliament ORG must retain the right to be informed and where appropriate also to react. Our rapporteur identifies very useful solutions to these difficulties which I and my group can only support in full. P I just have one CARDINAL more request. In the German NORP version paragraph 2 CARDINAL of the resolution has been translated rather misleadingly and I urgently ask for clarification which I would also like to see in the printed version later. In my view instead of weitergef hrt werden m ssen the wording should be erhalten bleiben m ssen . The German NORP version is not very clear here. I would ask for that to be checked again. For the rest I warmly thank our rapporteur. It is a difficult subject and I hope we have managed to make it somewhat easier to deal with now. SPEAKER ID 242 CARDINAL NAME Corbett Mr PERSON President I congratulate the rapporteur on her report. I must add that it is a welcome change to see Mrs Frassoni PERSON in such a conciliatory mood and willing to reach compromises with the other institutions. When it comes to the IGC she is one of what the French NORP call les pures et dures no compromise no deals with the other institutions we would rather see the whole thing blocked than compromise our positions. Yet here she is willing to accept the steps forward that have been achieved which are far from matching Parliament ORG s original position on the issue of comitology. P Let us remember what is at stake here. Parliament ORG had four CARDINAL main criticisms of the comitology system as it existed prior to the new Council ORG decision supplemented by this interinstitutional agreement. P Firstly the whole system is obscure. It is not transparent with hundreds CARDINAL of committees meeting with secret agendas and nobody knowing who is on the committees. Here is a real step forward in the new system that has been agreed. We are to know who is on each committee. We are to know when they meet. We are to get the agendas. We are to get the documents that are sent to them. The whole system will be more open and transparent if still rather complex. So that is at least a step forward. P Our second ORDINAL criticism is that the system was very restrictive of the Commission. We adopt legislation in the European Union ORG . We expect the Commission to implement it. And then we have a system designed to hinder the Commission and make it more difficult especially what was called the contre filet system under which the Council ORG could block the Commission by a simple majority even when the Council ORG was not capable of finding an alternative to the implementing measure concerned. Here too there is at least some progress. The Council ORG will no longer be able to block implementing measures indefinitely beyond the three month DATE period unless it has a qualified majority to block it in other words unless there is substantial opposition among the Member States represented in the Council ORG . That is a more reasonable system. That too is a step forward. P But on our other two CARDINAL criticisms we are less satisfied. The first criticism is of the system whereby the Commission is monitored scrutinised controlled if you like only by a committee appointed by Member States or the Council ORG not by Parliament ORG . The legislative authority Council ORG and Parliament ORG should be equal. We confer implementing powers on the Commission but then it is only a Council ORG or Member State appointed body that can blow the whistle and say no to the Commission and stop the implementing measure. Parliament ORG has no equivalent power. P True we are now given the beginning of such a power in this new system. We are to receive all the draft implementing measures forwarded to a committee at the same time as it is sent to the committee. We will have the chance to scrutinise to debate to question. But we will only have the right to formally challenge the Commission if we think it has gone beyond the delegation that we have given to the Commission in the legislation. In other words we can challenge the measure for being ultra vires but not on its content. And in a democracy Parliament ORG should be able to challenge the content. Not that we do so every week. We are not seeking to immerse ourselves in implementing decisions but it is a democratic safeguard that we should be able to do so on those few occasions when it really would be necessary. That is lacking in this new system or at least is only there in embryonic form. P Finally our fourth criticism is that if an implementing measure is blocked through the comitology system it is referred back not to both branches of the legislative authority but to the Council ORG alone which has the right possibly to take an alternative measure. That is not correct. Both branches adopt the legislation Council ORG and Parliament ORG that confers implementing powers on the Commission. If such implementing measures are referred back it should be to both branches not to one branch alone. P Overall we have a system which has made some progress. The supplementary aspects that arise from the interinstitutional agreement with the Commission ORG are welcome but that could not change the basic decision of the Council ORG . Even here we have renounced voluntarily because this did not happen automatically the Plumb Delors ORG agreement as part of the overall compromise. We have been willing to relinquish the provisions in that. We shall have to be very vigilant on what used to be covered by that agreement and is not fully covered by the new decision. We must be very vigilant. P So it is a step forward. My group reluctantly accepts it as a step forward. We are not as enthusiastic about compromising as Mrs Frassoni PERSON . We recognise that there are limitations and the issue will no doubt come back in a few years DATE time. If we want a Union that is democratic and transparent to the fullest degree we will have to revisit this subject. SPEAKER ID 243 CARDINAL LANGUAGE ES NAME Solbes Mira PERSON Mr President first I want to thank the rapporteur Mrs Frassoni for her work. It is never easy working on comitology. Mrs Schleicher referred to a kind of committee magic something we have long talked about. Certainly the process has always been very complex as a result of historical decisions and these must eventually be rationalised. P In my opinion the agreement reached between Commission ORG and Parliament ORG is a clear rationalisation of the process. From our point of view it satisfies the fundamental interests of Parliament ORG . Mr Corbett PERSON set out Parliament ORG s concerns. He says some of them have been satisfied and others have not. I would say the ones the Commission was able to satisfy have been satisfied. Mr Corbett PERSON is raising issues the Council ORG decision does not cover and unfortunately we can go no further on those. P So how far have we come? There is no doubt that we have reached a fundamental point highlighted by Mrs Frassoni given that we now have an automatic information system. This will facilitate two CARDINAL activities Parliament ORG is especially interested in. One CARDINAL is knowing how the committees operate about their composition agendas descriptions and so on and the other is the right of scrutiny over actual decisions. P I think this is a good agreement. It is a good agreement which undoubtedly improves the transparency of the process. From here on things are going to be easier. But the agreement we are reaching today DATE should not be regarded as a backward step compared with the Plumb Delors Agreement ORG . Mr Corbett PERSON referred to that but the new model is certainly much more complex different because the situation is now different and in our opinion much more coherent. We have made a start and we hope the work will produce some excellent results. P We think there are other positive advances too. To a certain extent we have gone beyond agreements which are already dated and by realigning old procedures with the new situation we aim to clear up everything still outstanding from the past. P From the Commission ORG s point of view our conclusion is that this is a good agreement and we want to thank the Members of Parliament ORG who worked on it especially Mrs Frassoni PERSON . We hope that this new climate means we have achieved the result we were seeking which is greater transparency and better information about the decisions of the Commission as an executive. SPEAKER ID 244 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you very much Commissioner Solbes Mira PERSON . P The debate is closed. P The vote will take place tomorrow DATE at 12.00 p.m. QUANTITY CHAPTER ID LAW 16 Protocol CARDINAL on the excessive deficit procedure SPEAKER ID 245 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is the report A5 0013 2000 by Mr Kn rr Borr s on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs ORG on a proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation EC ORG No 3605 93 on the application of the Protocol LAW on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the Treaty establishing the European Community ORG COM 1999 444 DATE C5 0174 1999 1999 0196 CNS ORG SPEAKER ID 246 CARDINAL LANGUAGE ES NAME Kn PERSON rr Borr s Mr President I am also pleased to welcome the Spanish NORP Commissioner Mr Solbes Mira PERSON whom I have congratulated more than once inside and outside this Parliament ORG on the excellent work he did in Spain GPE on the subject of European NORP convergence. P The proposal for an amendment to this regulation on the application of the Protocol LAW on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the Treaty of Maastricht raises fundamental issues concerning the switch to the 1995 DATE European NORP system of accounts which as you know replaced the previous System of Accounts adopted in 1979 DATE and in particular the emergence of new financial product categories consistency in the calculation of the ratios of government deficit to gross domestic product on the basis of ESA 95 FAC and finally recognising the importance of calculating interest expenditure and the consistency of the latter with this new methodology. P In our view the main purpose of the proposal for a regulation is to update the definitions and the assessments of some of the economic operations involved in the calculation of deficits as reflected in the Treaty establishing the European Community the Treaty of Maastricht ORG which lays down the maximum percentages which the government deficit must not exceed as a ratio of GDP at market prices in the various Member States. P To date the Member States have calculated this GDP in accordance with the criteria laid down in ESA 79. The most recent estimate of the deficit was submitted in September 1999 DATE and it relates to the 1998 financial year DATE . P Therefore if the regulation is adopted the estimate which is due to appear in March 2000 DATE the first ORDINAL estimate of the deficit for the 1999 accounting year DATE will be made using the new system. P We know the Member States have done their duty if I can use that expression doing their calculations and preparing their national accounts in line with ESA 95 ORG and they have already published their corresponding estimates. In addition to incorporating a new methodology this has meant making slight changes to most accounting aggregates and operations on account of the aforesaid methodological changes and also the improved statistical information included in the estimates. These changes may of course alter the government deficits in terms of the Member States national accounting. P I will now describe very briefly the five CARDINAL areas where the most important changes may occur. P First the adjustments to the scope of what is meant by government institutional sector under ESA 95 ORG . This is important since government deficit means the deficit accumulated by all forms of government. The non availability of precise criteria for the definition of government deficit would produce distortions in the estimates of the Member States government deficits. P Secondly the deficit or if applicable the surplus means the ESA 95 CARDINAL government sector s net borrowing requirement or lending ability respectively P Thirdly ORDINAL government investment means the gross fixed capital formation of the general government sector as defined in ESA 95 FAC . P Fourthly ORDINAL government debt is defined in accordance with ESA 95 LAW as are the flows or interest stemming from assets liabilities. P Fifthly ORDINAL and finally the aggregate to which government debt will relate will be gross domestic product at current market prices estimated in accordance with the 1995 DATE European System of Accounts WORK_OF_ART definitions. P To summarise I consider that this proposal constitutes a satisfactory adaptation of the criteria laid down in the 1995 DATE European System of Accounts WORK_OF_ART and I therefore approve it in full as did the committee. SPEAKER ID 247 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DE NAME Karas Mr President Commissioner let me say at the outset that my group welcomes this proposal because it makes the basic statistical data for an economic and monetary union directed at stability and real growth more harmonised directly comparable and more accurate. We have already heard about the various aspects involved. What I think is crucial is that henceforth the statistical data will be more reliable and comparable. We need that because the various European Union ORG bodies and all the Member States within monetary union have to be able to depend on one another. P It is important to adjust the procedure for two CARDINAL reasons. Firstly ORDINAL for the single market. It is most important quite generally in a single market to have reliable and directly comparable data and statistics so as to give an accurate picture of the situation and development trends. P Secondly ORDINAL for economic and monetary union. The regulation dating from 1993 DATE on the application of the Protocol LAW must be brought into harmony with the methodology of the European NORP system of accounts at national and regional level. That is vitally important to the accurate and reliable calculation of deficits. This adjustment will make it possible to estimate the deficits and debts in the Member States more precisely. These technical changes will have a very real impact on the actual position of the countries since the data will automatically be amended in line with the public deficit. P I also welcome the fact that the estimates of the deficits for the 1999 financial year DATE that are due to be published in March 2000 DATE are already based on the new ESA ORG i.e. the analysis is based on consolidated aggregates that are economically relevant. P Let me also briefly use this debate as an opportunity to urge all the governments and political parties to do their utmost to ensure that this procedure never has to be initiated for an excessive deficit. It is good that the procedure exists. We need it because it lends our criteria the necessary seriousness and credibility. The citizens ask what happens if the criteria are not met. Thanks to these procedures and other measures we can prove that we are taking the criteria and ourselves seriously. P Another important point is that we must do all we can not just to prevent excessive deficits but also to further reduce public deficits. P I know what I am talking about and I will conclude by telling you why I am so glad we are holding this debate! We are currently holding a debate in my own country on whether the former minister for finance actually gave us accurate information on the deficit. In my country Austria PERSON new elections had to be held in 1995 DATE in order to meet the Maastricht PERSON criteria and persuade our political partner to rethink his approach. I must also tell you that in the year 2000 DATE when there is so much talk about us the coalition talks with the SP NORP failed and unfortunately so because the Socialist Party ORG brought down the negotiated austerity and consolidation programme. That is a prime reason why the new government had to be formed in Austria GPE for the Austrian People s Party ORG the VP wants to continue to act as guarantor of economic stability. The VP wants to ensure that we continue to meet the Maastricht PERSON criteria and reduce the public deficit as we have agreed here. SPEAKER ID 248 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL NAME Maaten Mr President the beauty of statistical data is that it is not only reliable but also comparable. This is of great importance especially in the light of European NORP unification and the completion of the internal market. This is why this report is also so politically charged a report by the way on which we would like to congratulate the rapporteur warmly. P It also inspires a few political comments. The Stability Pact ORG is a given in Europe LOC . All countries participating in the euro have committed themselves in the medium term to striving towards a budget which is either balanced or shows up a slight surplus. This of course does not mean that if the economic climate is less than favourable the budget could not fluctuate up or down slightly. It means that in the long and medium term there should be a balance or surplus. P The stronger the position of the participating countries the stronger the euro will be. As a result the three percent PERCENT standard will rarely be exceeded not even in a bad economic climate. This is the theory behind it anyway. We have always been of the opinion that these criteria should be stringently met. That is of great importance in order to turn the EMU ORG into a success now and in the future. Strict compliance with the Stability Pact can thus contribute to a culture of stability within all EMU ORG Member States. P Various Member States have taken one off measures to be able to meet the criteria. We are of the opinion that the Member States budget policy should be strictly supervised to ensure that the measures continue to be taken in the spirit of the prescribed criteria at all times. A drop in standards should not be allowed. We are also of the opinion that a further reduction in the burden and reducing the national debt should be prioritised. Indeed we still have not managed to stop passing on the burden to future generations. SPEAKER ID 249 CARDINAL LANGUAGE ES NAME Solbes Mira PERSON . ES Mr President many thanks first ORDINAL of all to the rapporteur for his splendid work. It was a subject which called for a large dose of technical skill and I think Mr Kn rr has handled it with great precision and professionalism. I would not presume to be able to summarise the content of our proposal better than he has done I would just like to add one CARDINAL small point in addition to adaptation to ESA 95 LAW there are two CARDINAL small technical changes which Mr Kn PERSON rr knows all about relating to interest and the valuation of debt in foreign currency. I just mention that to complete the view of the process. P Secondly I would like to thank Mr Kn PERSON rr for his speediness. He has done really good work in a very short time. This is an important subject for certain references which we have heard subsequently. What we are seeking with this legislation is not to make the statistics reliable and comparable they already are but to make them more reliable and more comparable. Obviously the fact that Parliament ORG has taken its decision so quickly will mean that the March DATE figures can already be calculated on the basis of these new criteria. P That being so I believe the final result will be better. The figures will be more reliable and more comparable and I think the concerns some Members have raised about compliance with the stability pact can be better addressed. P This regulation is purely instrumental. It does deal with the substance of the problem some of you have raised. But we do need to think about how we deal with the substance of the problem. The stability pact is in place and we will continue to press ahead with monitoring compliance by the various Member States despite the fact that the results are clearly positive in all the Member States where we have analysed the position as regards the stability of the government deficit. But we see no reason to lower our guard. We must press on in that direction because we know it is vital. P So once again and finally I want to thank you for your help in allowing us to measure stability with greater technical certainty and better comparability. SPEAKER ID 250 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you very much Commissioner Solbes Mira PERSON . P The debate is closed. P The vote will take place tomorrow DATE at 12.00 p.m. MONEY CHAPTER ID 17 CARDINAL Increasing penal sanctions against counterfeiting of the euro SPEAKER ID 251 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is the report A5 0020 2000 by Mrs Cederschi ld on behalf of the Committee on Citizens Freedoms and Rights Justice ORG and Home Affairs ORG on a draft Framework Decision of the Council ORG on increasing protection by penal sanctions against counterfeiting in connection with the introduction of the euro 5116 1999 DATE C5 0332 DATE 1999 1999 0821 DATE CNS ORG . SPEAKER ID 252 LANGUAGE SV NAME Cederschi ld . SV Mr President ladies and gentlemen all the more welcome for being so few in number one might have thought that it was an unimportant subject which was to be discussed at this hour TIME but that is not the case. It is a definite and concrete issue. It is about our common currency. How many people here know that this currency is being counterfeited and that we have a quite unacceptable state of affairs? We cannot permit our common currency to become weaker through its being counterfeited. The ECB ECOFIN Europol OLAF and the Commissioner responsible for legal questions have therefore realised that common countermeasures must be taken quickly in order to close the loopholes left by the legislation. P It is easy to forget that it will be possible to exchange the old currencies for twenty years DATE after the new currency has been introduced. It is therefore important to include these currencies too in the section of the present programme of measures which deals with penal sanctions. This is something which Parliament ORG has said it wants to see added. P The Council ORG ought to have given Parliament ORG the stipulated three month DATE period within which to consider too the last document produced on this matter but we are all aware of how urgent it is to have these measures put safely in place. Because the issue is to be decided upon in March DATE in the Council Parliament ORG has cause to adopt a position on the proposal now so that the Member States have time also to take due account of Parliament ORG s points of view in the decision which has to be made in March DATE . P Any country which began to make difficulties would incur a responsibility for the currency and that country would be accountable both morally and economically if its actions were to contribute to a delay. A country which acted in that way would bring a lot of ill will upon itself. P On 1 January 2002 DATE the euro will be in circulation. The whole of the Union must have the same protection a type of protection which prohibits counterfeiting not only of currencies in circulation but also of currencies which will be in circulation. It is important that in time there should be a more or less similar looking form of protection under criminal law in all countries. The Commission ORG has proposed measures aimed at providing information together with penal sanctions preventive measures and the pooling of experience. These measures do in fact entail a certain necessary harmonisation in as much as the lowest acceptable maximum penalty for currency counterfeiting is to be eight years DATE imprisonment. Trading with counterfeit currencies and the possession of counterfeiting equipment will also become criminal offences. Quite simply we are to have a minimum level for the maximum penalty. P The denominations of the euro are well known. Modern computer equipment can be used to cause a very great deal of damage if we do not protect ourselves. Parliament ORG has tabled a number of amendments to the present proposal for example in regard to jurisdiction the idea being that a person may only be prosecuted and sentenced in the one CARDINAL country for the same crime. There are also proposed sanctions against companies which are involved in counterfeiting this being a measure which we would encourage. The new applicant States are also encouraged to adapt to these regulations. P It has taken two years DATE for the Council and the Commission ORG to produce this proposal. It is essential that the decision should now be taken in March DATE . To delay or perhaps even risk damage to the euro would be indefensible. It would also be a betrayal of the people who will be handling the new unfamiliar notes. In particular it is believed that counterfeiters will turn their attention to countries outside the euro zone where people are less familiar with the new currency. The protective measures cover these countries too and the views expressed by these countries have carried a lot of weight. The present proposal is therefore staunchly inclusive and reciprocal in character accepting responsibility for a variety of interests in a way which imposes obligations upon others. The Council ORG must now convene in March DATE and make the relevant decision. P Thank you for listening. Thank you too those who contributed to this matter s being dealt with swiftly. I am thinking in particular of the Group of the Party of European Socialists ORG . SPEAKER ID 253 LANGUAGE PT NAME Coelho Mr President first I want to compliment the rapporteur Charlotte Cederschi PERSON ld on drawing up this report which is an excellent point of departure for increasing protection by penal sanctions against counterfeiting in connection with the introduction of the euro. The euro will enter into circulation on 1 January 2002 DATE and will become one of the world s most important reserve currencies. Due to its importance on a world scale the euro will be particularly exposed to the risk of counterfeiting and forgery. This draft decision therefore lays down a set of minimum standards intended to harmonise criminal law in this field and make its application by each Member State simpler and more effective. It also provides for the euro to be protected even prior to its circulation which will fill a gap in legislation in some Member States. P I expressly support the rapporteur as regards the need to extend this protection to national currencies which can continue to be exchanged after they have been withdrawn from circulation. This means that every Member State must guarantee the establishment of effective adequate penal sanctions which act as a deterrent against the offences covered by the draft framework decision. P As to the proposal to establish a maximum custodial sentence of not less than eight years DATE I do not think that this will raise any problems as far as my country is concerned even though the maximum sentence for counterfeiting under its criminal code is currently five years DATE in prison as it has already expressed willingness to make this amendment. I also call on those few Member States still harbouring reservations to resolve them so that a decision can rapidly be reached on this matter for the reasons our rapporteur set out earlier when she called for this to be done. P Mr President this draft framework decision represents the first ORDINAL time a common proposal on crime has been put forward with legislation to be applied by all fifteen CARDINAL Member States at the same time. We are therefore making progress towards the aim of developing and confirming the status of the European Union ORG as an area of freedom security and justice as expressed at Tampere PERSON . SPEAKER ID 254 LANGUAGE DE NAME Schulz Mr PERSON President I need not repeat what the rapporteur said or the points Mr Coelho made. All that is indeed very true and correct. It is easy to counterfeit the euro. We are going through a dangerous transitional phase in which a phenomenon has appeared in criminal law that is perhaps unique in monetary history. It is that a currency that does not even exist yet that is not in circulation but exists only as bank deposit money can nevertheless be counterfeited already. Yet because that currency is not yet in circulation as such counterfeiting euros does not at present constitute a criminal offence. P It is a highly complex problem. If we do not act promptly as Mrs Cederschi ld rightly said anyone can produce a few counterfeit euros now and possibly not be prosecuted for subsequently putting them into circulation. Let me say in passing that this may seem an attractive prospect for a number of people. P So what is the European Union ORG doing about it? It is doing a number of things that are right as Mrs Cederschi ld has described but in the context of these things she described Parliament ORG must look not so much at the content of the framework decision not so much at the report drawn up by Mrs Cederschi ld but more at the procedures that are being applied. P The manner in which the Council ORG which is by far the most undemocratic institution in Europe LOC consulted the European Parliament ORG makes a mockery of the concept of democracy. We received a text for consultation which the Council ORG had been working on for a very long time incidentally with only partial success I will come to that in a moment. P Now the European Parliament ORG is supposed to state its position on this complex difficult and at times contradictory Council ORG document in the space of three months DATE . It is only thanks to the immense efforts of Mrs Cederschi ld and to Parliament ORG s decision not to stand by its democratic NORP right to conduct its advisory procedure over an adequate period of time and to have all the documents available in all the languages that we have now managed to give our position by the date set by the Council ORG so that the decision scheduled for March DATE can indeed be taken. P On a subject as important as counterfeiting and protection against counterfeiting and harmonising the necessary criminal law provisions we cannot really work at the ridiculous pace the Council ORG is demanding of us. So let me state quite clearly here on behalf of my group that we discussed at length with Mrs Cederschi ld whether it is reasonable to work like this. We concluded that it is not but given the importance of the issue we nonetheless agreed to accept this procedure. P This framework decision does without any doubt represent some progress. Only as Mrs Cederschi ld pointed out in the end it does not fully achieve the legal certainty the Council ORG wanted because various shortcomings have not been dealt with. They relate to the minimum rules we are seeking to establish the minimum rules relating to a punishable offence and in particular the application of the same criminal law norms in all Member States including those that have not yet introduced the euro but where it could theoretically be counterfeited. One CARDINAL reason they have not been dealt with is that as ever the leopard cannot change its spots i.e. in the case of this framework decision which specifically relates to judicial cooperation the Council ORG once again prefers to adhere to the level of government cooperation. That is why and I quote this framework decision is confined to supplementing the provisions of the International Convention of 20 April 1929 ORG for the suppression of counterfeiting and its Protocol LAW i.e. the provisions of a timeworn international convention that is a good 71 years old DATE . That means that the legal basis we are now seeking to establish to protect the euro does not derive from Community ORG legislation as it should but merely takes the form of provisions supplementing an international convention dating back 71 years DATE . P I leave it to the assembled company in this Chamber to decide whether that can be the future of a European Union ORG based on judicial cooperation. Thank you for your attention during our night sitting together. SPEAKER ID 255 CARDINAL LANGUAGE FR NAME Berthu NORP Mr President the launch of the euro could well be a heaven sent opportunity for counterfeiters. The fact is people are suddenly going to lose all their currency references and that means they will be at serious risk of easily accepting forged euros because they are not very familiar with the genuine article. So the Council ORG is naturally worried and is seeking to establish sanctions primarily criminal applicable in all the countries of Europe LOC against offences of this kind. P No doubt the Council ORG could have been satisfied with a simple resolution recommending that Member States adopt national legislation to that effect. That is what I would have preferred personally. But probably through lack of confidence in the zeal of certain members the Council ORG has preferred to implement a legal instrument which is more binding at European NORP level a framework decision. Now that is where the difficulties begin because criminal law comes under national sovereignty and the Treaty of Maastricht PERSON contains no specific provision covering this situation for the euro so as not to frighten the voters by over egging the pudding. P The draft framework decision before us today DATE tries to cover up this lacuna by referring to Articles 31 GPE and 34 2 CARDINAL b of the Treaty ORG . However I find these passports inadequate. Article 31 LAW only envisages minimum common rules for criminal acts in certain cases specifically restricted to organised crime terrorism and drug trafficking. Counterfeiting is not on the list. Article 34 LAW a product of the Treaty of Amsterdam GPE only lays down the new form of a framework decision and clearly this only applies to the existing powers of the European Union ORG . So we come back to the previous problem. In other words the Council ORG has not succeeded in giving this text a credible legal basis. In a way this is deferred punishment for its lack of honesty at the time in presenting the Maastricht Treaty LAW to the voters. P I would also like to make a more general point. Not so long ago we were dealing with one CARDINAL or more reports on questions of principle relating to the euro in virtually every part session. But there has been nothing for a year DATE . Just a few little technical reports like this one on counterfeiting. The Commission ORG s communication on its strategic objectives for 2000 2005 DATE which we have debated this week DATE contained absolutely nothing on this vast subject except the reminder in a single line that the euro coins and notes are due to come into circulation on 1 January 2002 DATE . P However there are many underlying problems yet to be resolved. Let us mention for example the disturbing lack of public interest the definition of monetary policy objectives abusively reduced to the mere fight against inflation the strange coupling of monetary federalism to a lack budgetary or fiscal federalism the status of the present applicant countries when they become members vis vis the euro zone the confused reaction of the international markets to this currency with no homogeneous popular foundation and so on. Do I also need to mention that investors who sold dollars to buy euros have lost 20 CARDINAL since 1 January 1999 DATE 40 if they bought bonds and no less than 55 CARDINAL if they sold yen to buy euros? Mr President for those unfortunate investors even real euros are false money. These are gigantic problems but they seem to be taboo here. SPEAKER ID 256 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DA NAME Krarup I should like to take over the baton from the previous speaker. There are a number of questions of principle which are demanding solutions because the point of departure is of course that the regulation of criminal law is a national concern. Criminal law is part of each individual nation s own cultural tradition and it is very difficult to arrive at common definitions of what is to be understood by these basic legal concepts. I appreciate Mrs Cederschi ld s PERSON work and my point of departure will be her search in connection with the Tampere Summit ORG for common definitions and common regulations regarding what is punishable and what common sanctions can be applied. She would like to devise these sanctions jointly so as to arrive at a coherent criminal justice system for offences which have particular relevance for the EU ORG . P But the problem is that there is no legal basis for this and with good reason because the regulation of criminal law belongs to the sphere of national jurisdiction. In that context I want to ask the following question of the Commission s and the Council s representatives ORG is the legal basis which has been invoked adequate? In my view it is clearly in conflict with and far exceeds the scope of Article 34 LAW paragraph 2 CARDINAL point b where a legal basis is established for so called framework decisions which are binding upon the Member States in regard to the desired objectives but in which it is left to the national authorities to determine the form and methods of implementation. What of course characterises the present draft framework decision is the fact that the Member States obligations are laid down in detail. There is no freedom of choice regarding methods and implementation. In my view this exceeds the parameters of the legal basis. I should like an answer from the Commission and the Council for I ORG consider it obvious that Article 31 LAW does not supply the relevant legal basis. SPEAKER ID 257 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DE NAME Karas Mr President Commissioner let me begin by warmly congratulating and thanking the rapporteur and pointing out that in her report she does not just welcome the draft framework decision but also proposes a few changes which have been referred to by various speakers but which we cannot discuss in detail now to supplement and improve the text. P It is crucially important to continue the success story of the euro and we must make every effort not to spoil this success story or put it at risk by taking inadequate measures to prevent counterfeiting and we are well aware of the initial attempts that are being made. We have all noted that the conversion phase will bring uncertainty and risks with it. So in addition to the efforts to combat counterfeiting to ensure the sound implementation of the provisions the planned information campaign will of course play a key role and here we still have serious work to do. P We are also concerned with the question of cooperation. We need to define the precise responsibilities of the ECB the national central banks the Commission and Europol ORG pertaining to all matters relating to counterfeiting of the euro. I also think we should perhaps consider setting up an interinstitutional or EU ORG body in charge of coordinating the cooperation work. In the same context we could establish an early warning system functioning round the clock together with a common information system for the rapid exchange of data between the responsible authorities. P Aside from the report which we welcome many questions have arisen that still need to be resolved. I hope the debate we are holding here will bring some clarification. SPEAKER ID 258 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DE NAME Schreyer Mr President Mrs Cederschi PERSON ld ladies and gentlemen how safe is the euro? That is after all a question the people often ask. And that question will of course become increasingly pressing with the approach of 1 January 2002 DATE the date when they will have euros in their pockets. For the safety of the euro is not just a matter of the stability and external value of the currency but in fact also of protecting the euro against counterfeiting. That too is a concern of the people for as has rightly been said this will be a new currency for them new in terms of how it looks and also how it is used. Of course all the citizens of the EU ORG Member States will also be faced with the novelty of a currency that is valid over such a wider area and even beyond Europe LOC as a reserve currency. They will need time to get used to that too. P So it is clearly necessary to ask what the EU ORG is doing to protect the euro against counterfeiting. And that is what we are discussing at this late hour TIME . This really is a subject that is close to the citizen so it is a pity it is being debated at such a late hour TIME . But that cannot be helped. P Of course the European Central Bank ORG has been looking into the matter for a very long time. After all it is responsible for technical measures to protect against counterfeiting. As has also been pointed out in summer 1998 DATE the Commission submitted a communication listing a very wide variety of areas where measures need to be taken such as information further training an important area cooperation between the euro states and of course even beyond them and measures under criminal law. That is what this framework decision is about. P Mrs Cederschi ld let me offer you sincere thanks on behalf of the Commission and above all let me also thank Parliament ORG for being prepared to give its position in the space of such a short time. I certainly appreciate that. P The framework decision aims to ensure that the Member States apply the same definition of counterfeiting offences. Of course the first ORDINAL condition for uniform action is always to have uniform definitions and as was emphasised what we are basically trying to do is to ensure that the euro is protected even before it is physically introduced. P Naturally the Commission is also glad that the European NORP Parliament ORG s prompt decision and I hope the vote will be in favour means the framework decision can enter into force very rapidly now so that we can begin to transpose it. For the Commission has been asked to report as it will in the first half of next year DATE on the progress in transposing it in the Member States on whether the serious nature of this issue is being matched by serious action. P It has been pointed out that this framework decision is in fact a decision in the area of criminal law. In that respect we must recognise this innovation this step even if as Mr Schulz PERSON just pointed out simply supplementing a rather old convention is not really a particularly bold step. In reply to the question whether the Commission considers that the framework decision has an adequate legal basis under the Treaty the Commission LAW believes that the right basis is being applied here. P The framework decision will however have to be supplemented by other legal acts in future. The Commission ORG will submit a proposal for a regulation on cooperation between all the responsible authorities and on cooperation with Europol ORG . That proposal will establish a duty to cooperate and a duty on the part of the national authorities to notify Europol ORG of cases of counterfeiting and to present any confiscated counterfeit money to the European Central Bank ORG for identification and classification so that effective measures can then be taken. P On the question of coordinating the various measures since early 1998 DATE the Commission followed now by OLAF ORG has been working with experts on the subject from the Member States the European Central Bank ORG and Europol ORG on means of effectively combating counterfeiting of the euro in advance. As Mr Karas just pointed out a few weeks ago DATE the Commission ORG submitted a proposal for an information campaign on the euro to which it proposed allocating as much as EUR 32 million CARDINAL . That is a volume of funding that can be put to very effective use a large amount and of course the information campaign will also focus very strongly on protecting the euro against counterfeiting. P I believe that this debate shortly before midnight will also teach a salutary lesson to all those counterfeiters who believe their hour has come because they think the EU ORG is no longer awake at this late hour TIME ! SPEAKER ID 259 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you very much Commissioner Schreyer. P The debate is closed. P The vote will take place tomorrow DATE at 12.00 p.m. TIME P The sitting was closed at 11.50 p.m. TIME
